title: Trump vows to sue BBC for up to $7.7bn over documentary edit
text:
aprilU﻿S President Donald Trump has flagged his intention to sue the BBC for up to $US5 billion ($7.7 billion) over its documentary edit, despite receiving an apology from the broadcaster.

The BBC apologised to the president after airing an edited ﻿version of his speech on January 6, 2021, splicing two parts of his address which took place almost an hour apart.

In a letter to Trump, the British broadcaster's chair Samir Shah personally apologised for the edit of the speech and accepted it "unintentionally created the impression that we were showing a single continuous section of the speech".

President Donald Trump speaks to reporters on Air Force One on his way to his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. (AP)

Trump's lawyer had previously sent the BBC a letter demanding an apology and threatened to file a US$1 billion ($1.5 billion) lawsuit.

The president said he still plans to sue the BBC, potentially now for a much larger sum.

﻿"We'll sue them for anywhere between a billion and five billion dollars, probably some time next week. I think I have to do it," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One.

"They've even admitted that they cheated."

The legal dispute was sparked by an edition of the BBC's flagship current affairs series Panorama , titled "Trump: A Second Chance?" broadcast days before the 2024 US presidential election.

A third-party production company spliced together three quotes from two sections of the 2021 speech, into what appeared to be one quote in which Trump urged supporters to march with him and "fight like hell."

The US president said he still plans to sue the BBC, potentially now for a much larger sum. (Jack Taylor/Reuters)

Among the parts cut out was a section where Trump said he wanted supporters to demonstrate peacefully.

Trump earlier declared the BBC was "fake﻿ news", adding that the people of the UK are "very angry" about the edit.

He said he would raise the issue with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

"I'm going to call him over the weekend. He actually put a call in to me. He's very embarrassed," Trump said.﻿

Director-general Tim Davie, along with news chief Deborah Turness, quit on Sunday, saying the scandal was damaging the BBC and "as the CEO of BBC News and Current Affairs, the buck stops with me."

title: Aussies pay this guy up to $5000 for what's in his mouth
text:
Dr Maheer Shah didn't even want to be a dentist; now he's using his dentistry skills to run a six-figure side hustle making jewellery for your teeth.

Grillz are removable dental accessories often made from gold and diamonds and Shah is the founder of one of Australia's only grillz businesses, Dr Grillz.

He can charge up to $5000 for a single removable set and right now, business is booming.﻿

Dr. Maheer Shah is a leading Perth dentist specialising in aesthetic dentistry - and making grillz on the side. (Supplied)

"Now I'm getting this demand for permanent work," Shah told 9news.com.au.

"I think the culture is moving in that direction – everyone's got so many tattoos now, and piercings, the permanent gold teeth and diamond teeth is probably the next phase."

Born in Nairobi and raised in the suburbs of Perth, Shah decided to pursue dentistry after hearing that a schoolmate's dentist dad only had to work three days a week.

He went in blind and admitted he didn't have much "natural talent". ﻿

But he persevered and completed his degree in 2015.

The idea for Dr Grillz﻿ struck him just a few weeks later, when he went to see his favourite DJs perform.

"I won some backstage passes, so I met them before their show and they had grillz in," Shah said.

These are grillz, removable dental accessories often made from gold and diamonds. (Supplied)

When he asked about the accessories, the DJs confessed they travelled abroad to buy them because grillz were so hard to find in Australia.

Shah immediately saw it as an opportunity.

After the show, his mates wanted grillz of their own, so he connected with designers and jewellers to create them.

It became a hobby, one he shared online via his Dr Grillz Instagram page.

Most of the dentists he worked with called it a "gimmick", insisting it wouldn't amount to anything.

But Shah's social media page had started to gain traction.

Before long, total strangers were reaching out to order custom grillz.

Still working full-time as a dentist, Shah slowly built a team of designers, jewellers and technicians to help bring each set of custom grillz to life.

Shah has built a team of jewellers, designers and technicians who keep Dr Grillz going. (Supplied)

He did most of the work for Dr Grillz between appointments or on weekends, but Shah didn't mind dedicating that time to a creative outlet.

And at up to $5000 a pop, grillz were becoming a lucrative little side hustle.

"A little silver tooth would maybe be $200 or $300, and if you wanted a little tooth gem that's somewhere between $30 and $50," Shah explained.

"But then, when the pieces start to get bigger, covering multiple teeth, then it'll move to that $500 to $1000 mark.

"And then when you add diamonds, or if they're very big pieces, it goes into the thousands – up to $5000."

He charges even more for permanent work, though it's not something he does often.

﻿On one occasion, Shah created a custom gold and diamond implant worth several thousand dollars to replace a patient's missing tooth.

This gold and diamond permanent tooth implant was created to fill the place where a client was missing a tooth. (Supplied)

But he's reluctant to do anything permanent that could damage a patient's natural smile – even though he could charge tens of thousands for it.

﻿"I'm still a dentist, my job is to protect your teeth," Shah said.

Dr Grillz is now a six-figure business and Shah will soon be opening a grillz studio in the Perth suburb of Northbridge.

Getting to this point hasn't been easy but the challenges he's faced building this side hustle are nothing compared to his day job.

"The mishaps you have in dentistry, the complications and pain and bleeding, is a way worse headache than grillz ever will be," he said.

﻿At least his Dr Grillz clients are happy to see him – unlike many of the patients he sees working full-time across two private dentistry practices.

﻿"When you work as a dentist, no one's really that excited to see you," Shah laughed.

Australian musician Mia Rodriguez shows off a custom set of grillz from Dr Grillz. (Supplied)

But he never considered giving up work as a dentist to focus on Dr Grillz alone.

About 55 per cent of Australians are currently earning money from a side hustle, or actively considering starting one, according to Westpac data.

Like many of them, ﻿Shah has had to play it smart with his money to keep his business going.

Without his salary as a dentist to fall back on, he doubts Dr Grillz would be as successful as it is today – if at all.

﻿He urged other Aussies looking to build a brand or make cash on the side not to dive into a side hustle without considering how they'll pay rent when business is slow.

Shah encouraged other Aussies pursuing side hustles to keep their day jobs and focus on making smart money decisions. (Supplied)

Because there's nothing ﻿that can kill a small business quicker than poor financial planning.

"If you can have a job that pays your bills and things like that, then all the money your side hustle makes, you can reinvest into the business," he said.

"And even if that business doesn't grow into something that makes you $1 million, it will lead you into that next thing that might be the golden ticket for you."

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Family faces fine over 'immaculate' lawn
text:
A Gold Coast woman is facing an ﻿$834 fine due to her family's "immaculate" lawn.

Amanda Blair uses a high quality synthetic turf at her home which is low maintenance and helps her partner's son's allergies.

"When my partner was mowing at the previous home, the smell and the grass clippings and things like that just set him off," Blair said.

READ MORE: Health star ratings could be mandated as industry fails to meet target ﻿

Amanda Blair uses a high quality turf at her home which is low maintenance and helps partner's sons' allergies. (A Current Affair)

The synthetic grass covers the front and back yards but it is the footpath patch that has made her local council see red.

In a letter, Gold Coast City Council advised her to rip it up or face further action.

"Get rid of it and put real grass down and then they will come in and inspect it," Blair said.﻿

While fake grass on private property is widely allowed, council laws vary on footpath rules.

Ipswich City Council, just like the Gold Coast, doesn't allow it. Brisbane, Logan, the City of Moreton Bay and Redland councils require residents to apply for permission.

Pedestrian safety is a big consideration when councils weigh up artificial turf.

Other factors can include the impact on neighbours and whether water can drain freely through it.

READ MORE: Australia now has a new leading cause of death

The synthetic grass covers the front and back yards but it is the footpath patch that has made her local council see red. (A Current Affair)

Gold Coast City Council fears turf could become a trip hazard and attract significant heat.

If residents don't comply they'll be fined $834 and council will remove the turf at the residents' expense.

Blair's local councillor Nick Marshall is sympathetic.

"This is a really good example of where the resident has a really good reason for why they're doing what they're doing," Marshall said.

"They keep it really well maintained so I hope we can get a good outcome."

title: Hidden issue in $80b tax leaving some Aussies thousands out of pocket
text:
The federal government is facing yet another call to overhaul the GST, with new research outlining the tremendous amount of unfairness baked into the current system.

The GST is the federal budget's third-largest source of income, behind income and company tax .

For 2022-23, the ATO collected $81.7 billion of it; the last federal budget forecast that figure will rise to $94.1 billion this financial year, and again to close to $100 billion in 2026-27.

Australians pay close to $100 billion in GST every year. But some cough up far more than others. (Photograph by Chris Hopkins)

While ostensibly a flat 10 per cent rate on all goods and services sold, the number of exemptions on certain products means some Australians are paying almost 50 per cent more GST than others, even though they have similar spending habits.

The findings were published in a new report from the e61-UNSW Policy Research Partnership earlier this week, which outlined the levels of inequity in the current arrangements.

"Only around half of items attract GST," study co-author Dr Matt Nolan said.

"Our research finds these exemptions are causing a significant inequity where households which spend or earn similar amounts overall end up paying hugely different amounts of tax."

According to the report, the amount of GST paid by low-spending households, who spend an average of $15,222 a year, ranges from $729 to $1354 – a difference of 46 per cent.

For an average household with about $37,500 in yearly expenses, there's a 37 per cent difference between the lowest and highest GST bills.

That figure eases again to 33 per cent for the highest-spending households, although in dollar terms that represents a difference of more than $2500 a year.

This is a clear example of "horizontal inequity", Nolan and fellow co-author Josh Clyne wrote, which brought about two clear issues in the tax system.

"As a fairness principle, horizontal inequity is bad as it involves making households contribute different amounts of tax when they have the same means to pay," the authors wrote.

"In terms of efficiency, taxing different consumption choices differently encourages people to change their decisions about what to consume solely due to taxation – leading households and firms to organise themselves in inefficient ways to avoid the tax (i.e. supermarkets no longer offering warm cooked chickens to focus on the untaxed cold cooked chicken substitute)."

Fresh food is exempt from GST, but other food products aren't. (Dominic Lorrimer/AFR)

A wide range of goods and services are currently exempt from GST, including fresh food, private health insurance, childcare, sunscreen, and charitable donations.

Nolan said a select few are the main culprits driving the inequity.

"For households with low spending or income, the main cause of the divergence is the type of food they buy," he said.

"While for high-spending and high-income households, exemptions for education and child care play a larger role."

The GST has frequently come under fire this year from economists who argue it needs to be broadened, given both sides of politics want to reduce income taxes despite the federal budget being in structural deficit.

Consumption taxes are seen to do relatively little economic damage, and compared to other nations', the GST is relatively low, at 10 per cent compared to the OECD average of 19.4.

UNSW economist Richard Holden and teal independent MP Kate Chaney put forward a proposal in August to increase the GST to 15 per cent and remove all exemptions from it .

Under the proposal, every adult would receive a $3300 "basics rebate", effectively providing a $22,000 GST-free threshold to ensure low-income households weren't left worse off.

Similarly, Nolan and Clyne called for all exemptions to be removed and to provide an annual rebate of around $900 to all adults, while keeping the rate set at 10 per cent.

They said the measure would be budget-neutral and remove the unfairness of the current system.

"In this scenario, people who earn and spend less are made better off, while those who are higher earners and spenders end up contributing additional tax," Clyne said.

"This is just one example of how GST could be redesigned so it no longer depends on what people buy.

"The exact form of compensation is up for debate, but it's clear we can reduce these horizontal inequities without punishing the most vulnerable."

title: 'What's going on?' Chaos erupts at Dubai triathlon
text:
Chaos has marred the T100 professional triathlon event in Dubai, with athletes confused over the number of laps they had completed on the bike and run legs.

New Zealand's Olympic silver medallist Hayden Wilde was the biggest casualty, the series leader missing the turn-off towards the second transition zone while leading the bike leg.

"He's missed the turn," Jack Kelly said in disbelief on commentary.

"Oh my God, he has missed transition. Jesus Christ Hayden, what are you doing?," added Jan Frodeno in co-coms.

"You're wrong buddy."

Loading Instagram content

According to some social media posts, it appeared there were cones still covering the entrance to the transition when Wilde passed it.

Regardless of why he missed the turn though, Wilde, second-placed Frenchman Mathis Margirier and Belgian Marten Van Riel all had to complete an extra 8 kilometre lap, with no opportunity to either communicate their error or for the trio to turn back.

"Guys seriously, how can you do this?" the commentator said.

Previously fourth-place British athlete Sam Dickinson rolled into transition and looked desperately confused as to where the leaders had gone, before setting off on the 18km run leg.

"I don't think they'll know what's happened," the commentator said as the new leading trio looked around at the empty bike stands on course.

Wilde, meanwhile, was left even more confused when he arrived in transition to see that he was not in the lead as he had expected.

"What's going on?" he shouted at a spectator as he set out on the first of eight laps of the 18km run leg.

"You've done one extra lap on the bike," the spectator was heard shouting back.

"F***'s sake. That's bullshit," he said.

Later in the run, he came up to race leader Morgan Pearson and asked him, "What's going on?"

"Apparently you did an extra lap," Pearson said.

"We did not. We were at 76k," Wilde replied.

"Were you?" a stunned Pearson said.

"Yes," Wilde spat in disgust, racing on to try to limit the damage.

He completed the fastest run leg by far with 49:19 for the 18km, but finished eighth.

Incredibly, that wasn't the last of the confusion.

Run leg brings more chaos

Towards the end of the eight-lap run leg, while the cameras focused on race leader Pearson, who was seemingly all set to win his first T100 race, footage immediately cut to German Mika Noodt crossing the line and raising the winner's tape.

Loading Instagram content

"No buddy, you have not won this race. Oh my god," the commentators said on the coverage as Noodt shrugged his shoulders, looked around and then could be seen asking "have I won?" on the footage.

"What is going on here?" said the co-commentator as Noodt shrugged his shoulders again and looked around before somewhat sheepishly celebrating.

"We're trying to work this out," the first commentator said, clearly baffled at what had taken place.

"Has Morgan Pearson now counted wrong as well?," the commentator postulated, trying to make sense of this latest turn of events.

"We're still trying to work out exactly what has happened here."

Sam Dickinson and Vincent Luis soon arrived behind Noodt, thinking they too had finished the race.

Confused, they then watched the arrival of Pearson, who was shocked to see that his winning moment had seemingly passed him by, hijacked by people he thought were behind him in the race.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

Wilde eventually flew home after a blistering run but was absolutely furious and demanded that the cameras leave him alone.

More than an hour passed as several athletes protested the result, with Pearson eventually crowned as winner.

The issue was a faulty lap counter, with World Triathlon and the Professional Triathletes Organisation (PTO) releasing a statement to that effect.

"Due to a technical issue with the lap counting board and timing, the official result for the Dubai T100 Men's race was determined after the 7th lap, which was the last known timing and follows World Triathlon guidelines," it read.

Although Pearson was justifiably crowned the winner, the organisers will be left red faced by the shambolic finish to the event.

Noodt was awarded second and Gregory Barnaby third. Luis was fifth, behind Jason West.

The T100 is a relatively new format, middle-distance race featuring a 2km swim, 80km bike and 18km run organised by the PTO, taking place around the world, with an event set for the Gold Coast in March 2026.

Olympic triathlon distances are 1.5km run, 40km bike and 10km run, while traditional half iron-distance races feature a 1.9km swim, 90km bike and 21km run.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

title: Librarian's toy story spanning six decades started in Sydney CBD
text:
Louise Sheather has lined the walls of a quaint church hall in a quiet corner of central west NSW with shelves of toys.

It is a world away from the bustle of Sydney's CBD, but the former retail guru can draw a line between the two.

"I was a management trainee at David Jones in the 70s and I got a toy department to manage," Ms Sheather said.

"It was so successful it ended up taking about a third of the floor in Barrack Street."

Clever software and stocktakes mean the volunteer-run Blayney Toy Library works like a retail store. (ABC Central West: Micaela Hambrett)

Ms Sheather said the toys had to be rolled down in shopping trolleys from the main Elizabeth Street store to meet demand, as the seasonal pop-up department grew to include toy company representatives giving live demonstrations and a gift-wrapping team.

"I walked around helping people telling them, you know, 'At this age, this is fantastic,'" she said.

"But what really rocked my boat was that every single child that got a toy knew it was going to work on Christmas Day."

Ms Sheather said that was because "every single toy was tested".

"If it had batteries, every single toy was sold with batteries separated out in the box," she said.

Savings for families

Four decades on, Ms Sheather is happy applying her vast retail and marketing insight to the tiny Blayney Toy Library.

Once again, her approach to her customers has yielded results.

"We love her," said Orange mum Kayla Melton.

Kayla Melton drives the hour-long round trip to Blayney because the toy library is so helpful. (ABC Central West: Micaela Hambrett)

"I don't know if we'd be there without her.

"She's like family — she just wants the best for your child.

"There have been toys there that Louise has suggested, and I'm like, 'Oh, no'. but they end up being [my daughter's] favourite toys."

Ms Melton said for $80 a year, her toy library membership had saved her "thousands" during a cost-of-living crisis.

"That's the price of two toys," she said.

"We're borrowing six toys every fortnight."

The Blayney Toy Library occupies a church hall on the main street. (ABC Central West: Micaela Hambrett)

Rallying community support

When she was just 10 years old, Ms Sheather donated a doll to a little girl with impaired vision.

It was a moment she will never forget.

"She just stood there and she felt all over it and just cried with sheer happiness," Ms Sheather said.

"It was so moving. It still moves me."

Ms Sheather spent a year convincing the Rotary Club of Blayney to get behind the library idea.

"I think they thought it'd be a bunch of screaming kids but they realised it was great for the community," she said

It took her a month to upload the almost 600 items into a sophisticated software system that allows their usage to be monitored.

Every single toy part is numbered by hand and regular stocktakes mean unpopular toys are periodically sold to raise money for new acquisitions.

Loading...

Ms Sheather said the meticulous work had given her a focus.

"I have an ill brother, and my best friend of 46 years died this year," she said.

"It's probably been the toughest year of my life.

" Being able to bring a bit of joy has been a really nice thing. "

Child development

In August, the library hosted speech and occupational therapists who provided free advice to families on the role of toys in childhood, especially for children experiencing developmental delays.

"We want therapists to recommend toys and then send families down here and say, 'You don't have to buy this expensive thing — your child is only going to need it for six weeks,'" Ms Sheather said

"Their brains are growing so quickly, they need constant stimulation."

Toy Libraries Australia (TLA) project officer Adelle Suitor said the benefits of temporary toys went far beyond saving money.

"113 million toys end up in landfill after one year, which is crazy," she said.

"But it is the social connection as well."

title: Government insists West Gate Tunnel is safe for walkthrough, reveals earlier Metro Tunnel opening
text:
The Victorian government has been forced to again defend the safety of the West Gate Tunnel as thousands of Melburnians took a first look at the new multi-billion dollar piece of infrastructure.

The government has also revealed major rail project, the Metro Tunnel, will open on November 30, a week earlier than previously announced.

The West Gate Tunnel is due to open to vehicles by the end of the year, but opened today for a "Discovery Day", allowing more than 50,000 people to walk through.

But the United Firefighters Union (UFU) urged people not to walk through the tunnel and told the government to call off the event due to safety concerns.

Melburnians got their first look inside the new West Gate Tunnel on Sunday. (ABC News: Leanne Wong)

Dozens of firefighters also gathered at the tunnel on Sunday morning to hand out pamphlets explaining why they believe the tunnel should not yet be declared safe.

UFU Secretary Peter Marshall said nobody should enter the tunnel until scenario testing had been completed.

"We know we don't have the capacity to access large parts of the tunnel if the air becomes unbreathable. We have no idea how our radios will work, or if they will work at all," he said.

"In some parts of the tunnel the only way out is through a maintenance tunnel beneath the roadway that carries high voltage equipment, can only be accessed by stairs, has an eight degree incline, and which may not have breathable air in a major emergency.

" In this environment, without any scenario testing having taken place, it is irresponsible to hold an event like this, and it should be called off until these significant issues are resolved. "

The government is yet to reveal exactly when the West Gate Tunnel will open to vehicles. (Supplied)

However, Transport Infrastructure Minister Gabrielle Williams dismissed the union's concerns.

"We simply would not be holding an event like this if it wasn't safe. We have emergency management plans in place. We work very closely with emergency services including Fire Rescue Victoria to make sure people are safe as they engage with this great new piece of infrastructure," she said.

"Safety is always at the forefront of our mind in both construction of this brand new piece of infrastructure and of course in time for us to open it to the public as well.

" We hold ourselves to the highest possible safety standards and we always will. "

She was backed by Major Road Projects Victoria CEO Duncan Elliot who said four of the final six stages of testing had been completed.

"All the systems are working now, absolutely. The fire deluge systems are in place," he said.

"The scenario testing is obviously much more aligned to vehicles in the tunnel and getting people out of vehicles and exiting the tunnel safely."

Ms Williams was unable to give an exact opening date for the tunnel but said the $10.2 billion project would be launched before the end of the year.

Williamstown Road to be truck-free at night

The government has also announced night-time and weekend truck restrictions on Williamstown Road once the tunnel opens next month.

Williamstown Road will be declared a No-Truck Zone from 8pm to 6am on weekdays and from 8pm Fridays to 6am Mondays.

"It's a terrific game changer for the community, we're going to see such a difference in the western suburbs with this iconic project," Road Safety Minister Melissa Horne said.

Trucks will be banned from driving on Williamstown Road in the evening and on weekends. (ABC News: Danielle Bonica)

The government has installed cameras along Williamstown Road to enforce the ban.

There'll be exemptions for grocery and parcel delivery vehicles.

The government said it is also rezoning land at Brooklyn and Tottenham to encourage container parks to move to better located areas.

Government brings forward Metro Tunnel launch

Premier Jacinta Allan also revealed the Metro Tunnel will open at the end of November, ahead of the previously announced launch date.

The tunnel was due to open in early December but Ms Allan said that opening has been moved forward.

Ms Allan said the confirmation and sign off from the national rail safety regulator had enabled the project to open earlier than scheduled.

"Over the next couple of weeks the final touches will be put to the timetable and the tunnel as we open the tunnel on November 30 with hundreds of additional services from November 30 that will be servicing communities across our city and state," she said.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese joined Ms Allan at the new State Library Station on Sunday to make the announcement.

"If there have ever been two leaders of respectively a state and a nation who are infrastructure nerds, you are looking at us right here," Mr Albanese said.

Melbourne's Metro Tunnel will open on November 30. (Supplied: Victorian government)

He said the pair had spoken about the project for a decade, since his time serving in the shadow transport portfolio while in opposition.

"This was unplugging the system. This was the key to growth. You couldn't do other things with the network unless you fixed this central congestion which was here," he said.

"That is what the Metro will do. It opens up the opportunity for further investment, further expansion. The key to people getting around major cities around the world is always public transport, including this great city here of Melbourne"

The tunnel will only carry a limited number of services until February, when a full timetable begins operation.

title: The 'takeovers' helping young people in regional areas have a voice
text:
Toby is a 17-year-old from Ballarat in Victoria, and while he is still in high school, he has had some big challenges to overcome.

His father was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2021 and brain cancer earlier this year.

"I sacrificed [by] missing school to make the trip to Melbourne to support my dad in each and every way," Toby said.

His dad is now recovering, but the experience and rehabilitation process have been tough for Toby and his family.

So, to help deal with the stress, Toby loves to sing and bowl.

He started singing five years ago, winning an award for his performance of Nutbush last year.

He is also a high achiever at the bowling alley, winning the local league in 2021.

"That made me feel really happy. It was the best time of my life," he said.

Allysa, 18, also faced challenges during her schooling.

Allysa says she had a good experience with alternative learning after being bullied in high school. (BTN High: Joseph Baronio)

"From like the start of year seven, I didn't have a very good start to high school.

"[I was] relentlessly bullied all year, and I just needed a way out," she said.

Allysa found her comfort in alternative learning, attending Yuille Park Community College, where she is the only year 12 student and the first to complete the Victorian Pathway Certificate.

Allysa said she was grateful for the opportunities alternative learning had given her.

She said other people could benefit from hearing how it had helped her.

John, 16, also attends Yuille Park Community College. He left home at 15, and his story is about becoming more independent.

He said it was important for others to hear stories like his because it might give them the confidence to speak up about their situations and raise awareness for youth mental health.

They are just three of more than 600 students from across Ballarat who have submitted their stories to ABC Takeover.

John is sharing his story about leaving home at 15. (BTN High: Joseph Baronio)

What is Takeover?

Takeover is a storytelling competition created to give young people aged 15 to 19 in regional areas the skills and platform to share their unique personal stories with the rest of the country.

It is run by a team that is also responsible for Heywire, a similar youth storytelling initiative for people aged 16 to 22 that has been running since 1998.

While Takeover has not been around as long, starting in 2022, the competition has broadcast the stories of 240 young people who live, work or study in Shepparton, Mildura, Melbourne, Lismore, Latrobe Valley, the WA Goldfields, and Burnie.

Takeover has broadcast the stories of more than 200 young people, including in WA's Goldfields. (ABC: Mark Eiden)

Now, the Takeover team has its sights set on Ballarat, where students such as Allysa say it can be hard for young people to have their experiences and opinions heard.

"It probably doesn't get out as much being the town it is," she said.

Her classmate, John, 16, said, "Mostly, everyone in Ballarat does go to Melbourne or interstate just to get their voice heard."

How does it work?

Takeover begins by carefully choosing an area to host its events to make sure they have maximum impact, by considering things such as the youth population, number of government schools, diversity, and socio-economic status.

Singing helped me survive depression and brain surgery Singing saw me through severe depression and brain surgery.

Once an area is chosen, Takeover facilitators visit schools and community groups and get to know the participants, asking things such as what brings them joy, what home means to them, what challenges they have had to overcome, and their strengths or skills they are working on.

Answers and ideas from those questions become stories and ultimately submissions for the Takeover competition.

Once written, the long process of reading each entry begins. There are more than 600 entries from Ballarat alone.

Just 35 winners will be chosen.

Six hundred entries in Ballarat will be whittled down to 35 winners. (BTN High: Joseph Baronio)

A panel of judges, including members of the local community and previous Takeover and Heywire alumni, helps pick the winners.

Swathi Shanmukhasundaram, who is a producer from Takeover, said narrowing it down could be very tricky.

"There are multiple things that go into it. The most important thing is: is this young person passionate about the thing that they're sharing? Is there a story structure in there that the producer can play with? And some of our best entries come from stories that were two lines."

Swathi Shanmukhasundaram says young people, who do not see themselves as leaders, grow through Takeover. (Supplied: Swathi Shanmukhasundaram)

The winning stories are then broadcast on ABC television and radio.

Takeover ends with a five-day summit that showcases the 35 winners' stories, with a red-carpet screening and ideas presentation.

The winners can talk with leaders about how to make their communities a better place to grow up in.

"They get leadership development, they get opportunities, and they're not always related to what's in their story," Swathi said.

"Sometimes it's about funding for their community, about learning something new, making friends. You never know what will come out of it.

" The growth that I've been able to see in some of the young people who don't traditionally see themselves as leaders is probably the most beautiful outcome for me. "

The Takeover Ballarat Summit will take place in June 2026, and entrants such as Pat, 15, from Ballarat Specialist School say it will be an important event for the community and young people across the country.

Pat says it is important young people have an opportunity to talk about how they feel. (BTN High: Joseph Baronio)

Subscribe to the BTN Newsletter Do you want to be notified when the next BTN High stories arrive? Join our weekly newsletter.

"I feel like young people definitely do deserve a chance to talk out their feelings, because of course, a lot of people have been saying they're the new generation. They're probably going to lead the world," Pat said.

Alyssa said, "I think it's important for all young people to tell the adults how it is and share their story and know that not everyone's the same, but we can all learn to accept each other."

"The more we share, the more it can inspire other young people."

title: Buying a business and place to live for the price of a house in Brisbane
text:
Katherine Trembath has just bought an outback pub for the price of a house in Brisbane.

The 73-year-old said she was soaking up retirement in the seaside town of Hervey Bay when the Winton Hotel in central-west Queensland came calling.

"I was doing a trip around Queensland, and I thought, 'I need to be back out in the country', came across the pub and thought, 'Yep, this is the one,'" she said.

Ms Trembath said it was her fourth time "out of retirement," having owned motels in regional Queensland for more than 20 years.

Katherine Trembath has spent the past week learning the ropes from Kevin and Jo Fawcett. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"I like being active and you can't be more active than running a pub," she said.

Accommodation broker David Faiers sold Ms Trembath the hotel and said although she had decided to come out of retirement, the price of housing in coastal areas was a driver for outback pub and hotel sales.

Mr Faiers was tight-lipped on the final sale price, but he said it was not too far off Brisbane's median house price of $1.126 million.

"What's changed is the cost of housing," he said.

"For a hotel like the Winton Hotel, for under $1.5 million, you buy a residence and [you can make] an income.

"[If] you go to the coast for instance, you don't get much for a million dollars anymore."

In her first week, Ms Trembath said she had learnt that everyone in Winton had a nickname and she was not allowed to change anything in the establishment.

There is a lot of history on the walls of the hotel, built in 1899.

The Winton Hotel in 1907. (Supplied: State Library of Queensland)

"I won't change anything; I'll just enhance it," Ms Trembath said.

"This is a family pub where locals can relax and enjoy the atmosphere."

Former owners Kevin and Jo Fawcett said they wanted to hand over the keys to the right person after running the hotel for 27 years.

"We turned away 10 or 12 prospective buyers until we found a nice lady to take the reins," Mr Fawcett said.

"That was important to us."

Jo and Kevin Fawcett sold the Winton Hotel to Katherine Trembath. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

He said it was their turn to retire to the coast.

"The fish and mud crabs are calling my name of a night-time," Mr Fawcett said.

'Live and do business'

Winton, a town of fewer than 1,000 people, boasts four pubs.

But the tourist season between May and October means thousands of thirsty travellers pass through.

In the past 12 months, Mr Faiers has sold two pubs and a motel in Winton.

He said sales across Queensland had been exceptional.

David Faiers says hospitality businesses such as hotels and motels are a place to live and a source of income. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"The market is very strong; there's a lot of natural migration," he said.

" People have identified that hospitality businesses, both hotels, motels and caravan parks, are a good source of income; it's a growing market, it's somewhere to live and do business. "

In the nearby town of Longreach, a privately owned Australian hotel and property group has been snapping up businesses.

Waymark Hotels now owns two pubs and a restaurant in the popular tourist town.

But Winton sales have remained with individual buyers.

Bernie Hogan, chief executive of the Queensland Hotels Association, said interest in regional hotels had increased in the past 18 months.

"I think people have realised what great businesses they are, what great investments they can be … and, as always, people … are looking for that change of lifestyle," he said.

"There are many success stories of people heading west and loving it."

The Australian Hotel in Winton was sold earlier this year. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

But Mr Hogan said running a regional pub was still challenging, with rising costs and transient staff.

Mr Faiers said sales worked in a cyclical nature.

"It's pretty typical what we see in the market — when somebody sells a business, other local business people are surprised with the value … it makes them start to think about their position and what their next steps are," he said.

"The cost of buildings [are] not dissimilar to housing, it's hard to get something built.

"That's helped the older buildings and businesses become more valuable, the structure is already in place."

title: Wong won't put price tag on COP31 as final host decision looms
text:
Foreign Minister Penny Wong has refused to say how much it would cost Australia to hold the COP31 climate conference, as negotiations over hosting rights enter the final stages.

Australia has pitched to hold next year's meeting in Adelaide in "partnership" with Pacific nations, but has been locked in a stand-off with Türkiye for months, with both parties refusing to cede their bid.

Climate Minister Chris Bowen is currently at this year's Conference of Parties (COP) meeting in the Amazonian city of Belem, where he will continue to push Australia's case.

But even as the final decision on where the conference will be held looms, Senator Wong would not be drawn on the price tag if Australia's bid is successful.

Some reports have put the potential cost at up to $2 billion, but the minister did not say whether that was accurate when it was put to her.

"I'm not going to comment on the costs of a conference that we haven't won the bid for yet," Senator Wong told ABC's Insiders when asked repeatedly what the cost would be.

" Obviously, those costs would be finalised, including with the state government and the scope of the bid. "

The foreign minister said she anticipated that there would be a resolution to the deadlock by the end of the coming week, when this year's conference comes to a close.

If both countries are unable to come to an agreement, hosting rights will default to the German city of Bonn, home of the United Nation's committee.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is due to travel to the G20 summit in South Africa next weekend, where Türkiye's President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan will also be in attendance.

Senator Wong said the prime minister was "looking forward" to seeing the president but would not say whether the issue would be raised.

"Obviously, what the Pacific want for the conference and what Türkiye want are very different. So, we're going to keep advocating for the Pacific COP," she said.

"What I would say is, this does need to be resolved."

Decision set for coming week

The government has already spent $7 million preparing to host the conference, Mr Bowen said on Saturday before he departed for Brazil.

He also confirmed that a decision would be made this week, noting that Australia had "overwhelming support" for its bid.

But because the decision was not made through a traditional ballot process, he said, the government would have to reach an agreement with Türkiye.

"That makes it difficult," he told reporters.

"I'll continue to have conversations with my Turkish counterparts in consultation with the Pacific over the next week or so, and we'll see how we go."

The government has said it wants to use COP31 to highlight urgent climate threats faced by Pacific nations and champion their calls for more ambitious action.

Türkiye has previously proposed sharing the COP presidency with Australia, but the ABC understands the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Secretariat has made it clear that co-presidencies are not permitted under its rules.

Climate change debate swirls at home

The last ditch push for COP comes as climate change and emissions reduction dominated domestic political debate, after the Liberal Party this week announced it would join the Nationals in ditching its commitment to reach net zero by 2050.

Senator Wong on Sunday characterised the opposition's decision as "trying to outflank Pauline Hanson".

"And what I'd say to Sussan Ley — and to Andrew Hastie and to Angus Taylor — is you can't be more Pauline than Pauline," she said.

The conundrum at the core of the Coalition's net zero backflip Liberal shadow cabinet members landed on a plan that has left many inside and outside the party bewildered and confused.

She added that the opposition's "confused, divided" approach to climate policy would result in higher costs for Australians, while the Coalition has argued that ditching the target is necessary to bring down power prices.

The prime minister also took aim at the Coalition during a press conference on Sunday, describing its approach to climate and energy policy as a "clown show".

"The real problem is that that kills off investment certainty, that kills off investment, and less investment means higher power prices," he said.

Opposition Leader Sussan Ley this week confirmed the party would remain in the Paris Agreement and would continue to set five-yearly interim targets from government.

And while the party would not actively strive for net zero, she said reaching it would be "welcome".

The Coalition will hold a joint-partyroom meeting on Sunday to determine a final policy.

Liberal frontbencher Jonathan Duniam, who is part of the team leading the negotiations, said the ultimate decision would be in line with what the two parties had already announced.

"The key difference between our approach to this, and the government's, is we're focused on energy affordability," he said.

"They're focused on emissions reductions, no matter the cost. And that has cost Australia dearly."

title: Fourth case of measles confirmed after Jelly Roll concert
text:
A fourth case of measles has been confirmed after last month's Jelly Roll concert in Brisbane, prompting authorities to urge attendees to be alert for symptoms.

Queensland Health's metro south unit said a person with the virus had been identified in the Logan region, after three cases linked to the October 24 concert at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre were confirmed on Wednesday.

The person was unknowingly infectious while visiting a number of places, including Mustangs Brothers Football Club on November 8, Mullein Pharmacy at Hillcrest on November 12 and Logan Hospital Emergency Department on November 12, 13 and 14.

"While these locations do not pose an ongoing risk, people who attended these locations during the same time periods may have been exposed to the virus and should monitor for symptoms," the metro south public health unit said in a statement.

"Contact tracing is underway and those who are identified as being exposed will be contacted."

Health Minister Tim Nicholls said contact tracing was continuing, with almost all of the cases coming from overseas.

"Anyone who has symptoms … I would say to you get medical advice but please don't come to an emergency department because that is how it gets spread," he said.

"What we want to do is make sure people are treated appropriately but we contain the spread of measles."

Measles is a highly contagious infection which can be associated with severe complications.

Symptoms can include fever, a runny nose, a moist cough and sore eyes as well as a blotchy red rash.

It can start on the face and spread across the body.

The time from contact with the virus until onset of symptoms is typically 10 days but may be anywhere up to 18 days.

The most up-to-date list of locations can be found on the Queensland Health website.

People who believe they have measles symptoms are urged to arrange testing with their doctor or call 13HEALTH (13 43 25 84) for advice.

title: Fractures and leaks in WA Labor's third term a blip, or a sign of more?
text:
The longer a government is in power, the more time it has to lay traps for itself.

Accusations of secrecy and abuse of process have been levelled at the Western Australian government this week on several fronts.

On one end, the government was accused of hijacking the historical sexual abuse case of Dion Barber to protect its coffers.

On the other end, accusations were made about the government altering a secret report to justify its claims about fossil fuels.

The government has also been accused of altering a report to justify its claims about fossil fuels. (ABC News: Brendan Esposito)

When the stories came to a head on Wednesday, WA Labor MP Sabine Winton diligently defended the government despite having little to do with the decisions behind these particular issues.

"We're not going to shy away from difficult conversations," she said.

But critics say that is exactly what the government is trying to do.

Path to self-destruction?

Lawyer slams government's Dion Barber appeal A lawyer accuses the WA government of hijacking a case of historical sexual abuse to "clarify law", instead of legislating it through parliament, because it would be "political suicide".

In 2018 the WA government removed the time limit for survivors of historical sexual abuse to take legal action.

The government made it easier for abuse survivors to seek justice and now, surprise, surprise, more abuse survivors are seeking justice, and the state may have to fork out more in compensation.

The state of Western Australia is taking Dion Barber's $2.8 million compensation case back to court to try and limit its potential liability in future cases, or as the government keeps saying, to "clarify points of law".

Dion Barber was abused by his stepfather as a boy, taken into state care, and then sent back to live with him again. (ABC News: David Weber)

The government could try to seek clarity by introducing legislation through parliament, according to abuse lawyer Juliana Fiorucci, but won't.

"Because doing so flies in the face of celebrating being the government that enacted the legislation to allow these claims to pass in the first place," Ms Fiorucci said.

" That would be political suicide. "

Right or wrong, it seems the government may be trying to protect its bottom line while avoiding the difficult conversations.

"Some might say pursuing the appeal in those circumstances could be an abuse of process," Ms Fiorucci said.

Juliana Fioruccia says the government could seek clarity by introducing legislation through parliament. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

Attorney General Tony Buti said while he acknowledged Mr Barber's courage, it would be inappropriate to comment further as the matter was before the courts.

It doesn't look great when the government gives with one hand, but takes with the other, which may be why it seems like it's trying to keep the issue at arm's length.

Premier Roger Cook literally said the appeal of Mr Barber's case was "at arm's length" because it was being sought by the government's insurance arm, the Insurance Commission of WA.

Secret report altered

In another potential example of keeping its distance, the government quietly released a secret report this week that was supposed to justify claims WA's fossil fuels are critical to helping the rest of the world reach net zero.

One would think the government would jump on the opportunity to laud a $402,000 report it commissioned that supported its campaign to expand WA's gas industry.

The role of gas in Australia's energy transition is heavily contested. (ABC News: Andrew Seabourne)

But the report was tabled in parliament — eight months after it was finalised — just days after a draft version was leaked highlighting the "substantial" risk that WA's gas could hamper the transition to renewables.

The problem is, the government published the final report with changes throughout, which could be clearly compared to the original draft.

Among the changes, Asia's projected gas consumption was altered dramatically (it somehow doubled), and language describing the risks of gas was softened.

The government insisted the report by consultancy firm Deloitte "was drafted and revised independent of government", and said both the draft and the final versions supported its claims about the need for WA's gas — a claim rejected by the WA Greens.

Sophie McNeill says the tabled report downplays the risks of fossil fuels. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

"They sat on it for months, they hid it from the public, and now they've come out with a version that downplays the risks," WA Greens MLC Sophie McNeill said.

"I just can't believe what an own goal this is by the government."

United front under strain

There are questions to be asked about the veracity of these consultancy reports that underpin government policy.

What has become clearer, however, is the longer a government is in power, the more difficult it is not to contort itself.

In the last week alone, an insider leaked the confidential gas report, and Labor backbencher Dave Kelly publicly spoke out against the appeal of Dion Barber's case — rarities in a government known for its solidarity.

It remains to be seen if this week's events are just blips, or fractures in a government wading through its third term in power.

title: More than 10,000 children poisoned by free school meals in Indonesia
text:
Within minutes of eating a school lunch of chicken, rice, salad and strawberries, Aldo Revaldo started getting very sick.

"After finishing the food, I felt a headache, then a stomach-ache," the 17-year-old said.

"Then I struggled to breathe."

All around him, one by one, his classmates were also succumbing to a painful and overwhelming sickness.

Footage from the school in Indonesia shows teenagers convulsing, vomiting and crying with pain.

Students seen receiving treatment at the Cipongkor District Hall in September. (ANTARA: Abdan Syakura)

Ambulances took the sick children to a nearby sports hall and a town hospital, where some had to receive oxygen.

Aldo's father, Ade Jalal, said there was hysteria and mass panic.

"Parents there were crying," he said.

Mr Ade said he found Aldo in the corner having seizures.

In a video that went viral on TikTok, Aldo was filmed on a stretcher, crying in pain and foaming at the mouth.

"Both his arms were tied to the folding bed," Mr Ade said.

"They had to hold him down to put the IV [intravenous drip] in."

Loading...

Aldo and his classmates fell ill after eating meals provided by the Indonesian government's Free Nutritious Meals program, known locally as MBG (Makan Bergizi Gratis).

The program was Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto's key election promise.

But since launching earlier this year, it has caused thousands of cases of food poisoning in children.

More than 130 children from Aldo's school in Cipongkor, West Java, were hospitalised in the mass outbreak of food poisoning in September.

Across the region, more than 1,000 children fell sick over the span of a few days.

But across the country, more than 10,000 have been poisoned since the program was launched.

Estimates vary but JPPI, an Indonesian education-focused NGO, believes more than 16,000 children had become sick after consuming the food.

The Indonesian government's own figures, revealed in a parliamentary hearing last week, said 13,370 people had experienced "health problems due to poisoning".

Despite the controversies, the government is pushing ahead with expanding the program.

Plans to double number of free meal kitchens

The president's pitch was very popular: free meals for every school-aged child and pregnant mother, every single day.

The MBG program's goal was to address stunting, a condition where children's height is lower than average, often because of malnutrition.

But the program has been marred by poisonings, as well as concerns over its cost and allegations of corruption.

Loading...

In some incidents, students in East Java and South Sulawesi found maggots in their meals, while children reportedly found shards of glass in rice in meals in the Riau Islands.

Footage of mass poisonings play on Indonesia's local news regularly, galvanising a strong response across Indonesian NGOs and mothers' groups, who have called for the program to be suspended.

But there are still many supporters.

The free meals are popular with the enormous number of Indonesian families who live in poverty, or those who find feeding their children difficult when faced with the increasing cost of living.

The free meals program's rollout began earlier this year. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Indonesia's National Nutrition Agency (BGN), which runs the program, said by the end of the month, it wanted to be providing weekday meals to more than 75 million children and pregnant mothers.

More than 14,000 kitchens across the country have been set up to support the program — and the nutrition agency wants to double that by next year.

Many kitchens are run with oversight by Indonesia's military.

Local media has also reported that many kitchens are managed by local politicians, members of parliament, or residents near the kitchen sites.

In the wake of mass food poisoning events in September, Indonesia's president acknowledged "deficiencies" in the program. The government then issued kitchens with a range of guidance notes on sanitation, supervision, sterilisation and testing.

Prabowo defended the record of the program, claiming the "percentage of error" of meals that caused sickness was just "0.0017 per cent".

BGN head Dadan Hindayana also apologised, admitting "negligence".

Parents have held protests in the wake of the food poisoning outbreaks. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Cases of food poisoning have been blamed on improper ingredients and storage, poor sanitation, poor water quality, and slow meal distribution times.

At a parliamentary hearing on November 12, Mr Dadan identified another possible culprit: high nitrite levels in food.

"We found that nitrite infection is quite high, possibly because of farmers' cultivation practices providing too much nitrogen," he said.

"This results in high nitrite content in the plants, leading to frequent poisoning."

Over the last few months, more than 130 kitchens have been suspended following poisoning events, with some reopening following testing and training.

But cases of food poisoning do not appear to have slowed down.

Blame on 'kitchens that did not follow the rules'

The government has issued guidance to kitchens on sanitation, supervision, sterilisation and testing. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

At a kitchen in East Jakarta, BGN-appointed kitchen head Tommy Afoan said kitchens had been ordered by the president to send in samples for testing, improve food quality, and recruit professional chefs.

"Based on our experience, food poisoning could be attributed to raw ingredients, contamination during storage, production or transportation," he said.

"There are so many factors … so we need mitigation on every level, to follow strict procedures to minimise the risk.

"I feel sad seeing the children suffering in hospital, caused by kitchens that did not follow the rules."

Tommy Afoan says kitchens have been ordered to improve food quality. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Kitchen nutritionist Achyar Fuadi said lab tests had been carried out for salmonella and E. coli.

"In some cases, small, remote kitchens don't have experience," he said.

"A problem could come from workers that are inexperienced, nutritionists that are less detailed … this could all lead to food poisoning.

"I work here for 12 hours from 6pm to 6am nonstop, to make sure things are correct."

Achyar Fuadi works 12 hours a day to make sure the kitchen is up to scratch. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

BGN spokesperson Dian Fatwa said that for the agency, food safety was "non-negotiable".

"This is a challenge of growth, not of neglect … this is a living system and we learn every day," she said.

"Every bowl, every plate we serve to the kids, it carries a duty of care, so one case is too many for us.

"This is not a perfect story, but this is a story of progress."

Protesters want program paused and reviewed

The program has also drawn criticism from civil society groups, frustrated at the amount of money the government has allocated for it in the budget.

BGN said it expected to spend more than 99 trillion Indonesian Rupiah ($9 billion AUD) this year.

But the costs could more than triple, with the program reportedly budgeted for 335 trillion Indonesian Rupiah next year.

The government eventually aims to provide free school lunches to more than 70 million children and pregnant women. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

At a recent protest against MBG outside the nutrition agency's Jakarta headquarters, mothers voiced their anger over the poisonings and the cost of the program.

Nada Arini from the Indonesian Mothers Alliance said the government had sacrificed education funding.

"They need more targeting of children, especially the most remote, poorest and farthest areas from development," she said.

"I want this MBG to be stopped, evaluated and back to the drawing board."

Nada Arini is worried about the safety of the free food program. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Bhima Yudhistira Adhinegara, executive director of legal and economic think tank CELIOS, said any program aimed at improving childhood development and lowering malnutrition rates should be more specific.

"It should target poor children from the poorer family backgrounds," he said.

"Other alternatives like cash transfers might be better."

Dian Fatwa says that for the agency, food safety is "non-negotiable". (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

Ms Dian said she was optimistic the program would achieve its aims.

"This nutrition intervention is starting when the mother is pregnant," she said.

"From the tummy to high school, we are feeding [children].

"The parents, the teachers, they see the benefits … the kids can study more, in the weight of the kids they can see an improvement."

Kids still 'traumatised' by mass food poisoning

Despite the calls for a moratorium on the program, it is unlikely to be paused, as the nutrition agency is ramping up the number of kitchens and recipients.

At the parliamentary hearing earlier in the week, the nutrition agency's chief said 1.8 billion portions of food had been produced.

The ABC visited the kitchen at the centre of the school outbreak in Cipongkor, which was undergoing refurbishments.

Ade Jalal with Aldo Revaldo, who still feels traumatised by the program. (ABC News: Tim Swanston)

The school said it felt it should be consulted before the free meals program was brought back to its classrooms, as the children were still processing the mass food poisoning.

"We still feel it," Aldo said.

"I don't want to eat the MBG again, my friends and I feel traumatised."

title: Victorian farmer says goodbye to vintage tractors prized by late dad
text:
Tony Forrest farms at Ripplebrook in Victoria's Gippsland region, where his cows share paddocks with more than 200 vintage tractors.

"As a kid I gravitated towards everything from tractors, stationary engines, cars, trucks, petrol bowsers," he said.

"Anything that was older than me, pretty much."

Tony Forrest Sr collected vintage tractors for 40 years. (Supplied: Tony Forrest Junior)

Mr Forrest shared his passion with his father, the late Tony Sr, for decades.

"My dad mainly worked on bulldozers, so he'd buy a bunch of them, use them for a few months and then flog them off," Mr Forrest said.

"By the 1980s he had 150-odd bulldozers scattered around the place."

Tony Forrest has been busy preparing his vintage tractors for sale. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Tractor trove

For more than four decades the father-and-son team sourced tractors from around Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia.

"Dad and I used to travel all over Australia, buying and selling machines from John Deere, Massey Ferguson, Ford etc, so I caught the collecting bug pretty quickly," he said.

"When I got a bit too serious, I started importing them from America, England, Belgium, Germany, Holland — all over really."

Mr Forrest says Lanz Bulldog tractors are some of his favourites. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Mr Forrest said there was strong overseas demand for his vehicles.

"I'm sending three tractors — a Lanz Bulldog, a Fordson P5 crawler and a Mercedes-Benz 800 — to someone in the Netherlands and they send other machines back to me in containers," he said.

Mr Forrest said he preferred older tractors.

"For starters, the antique models don't have computers, so you don't have to be a tech whiz to fix the darn things and they tend to be more reliable too," he said.

A Mercedes-Benz tractor sits in Mr Forrest's paddock. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

But Mr Forrest said there was a fine line between collecting and accumulating.

"I've lost count of how many I have," he said.

"I've sold a dozen in this first auction and only plan to keep about 50.

"I've got a little 1954 Ferrari tractor which is extremely rare, because Enzo and his cousin only built 13 of them.

"And there's also my 1937 Vierzon, which is a French copy of a Lanz Bulldog, although I love all my Bulldogs."

Tony Forrest has been collecting antique machinery for decades. (Supplied: Tony Forrest)

Saying goodbye

Mr Forrest said collecting went on the backburner after his father's death in 2018.

"After he passed away, life changed a whole lot," Mr Forrest said.

He took over the family's dairy farm and decided to sell some of his father's tractors.

"We've only got 226 acres, which is not enough room for cows and a whole tractor collection," Mr Forrest said.

"But I also realised there's no point them rusting away when someone else could repair, restore and actually enjoy them."

Tony Forrest and his late father collected various tractor brands, including Fordson. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Mr Forrest said selling the tractors would take time and tug at the heartstrings.

"I'm planning a bigger auction around May 2026, but I expect I'll still be sifting through the collection for another couple years," he said.

"Dad loved his tractors, so it's definitely difficult to let them go.

"The ones I'm most sentimental about are still tucked away in the shed under covers because I haven't even thought of getting rid of them — but you just can't keep them all."

title: Through dust and drought, these women are redefining resilience
text:
Dusty paddocks, with no grain crop to harvest, and scarce feed for the few animals left.

That is the harsh reality at fourth-generation farmer Louise Smith's property at Maggea, 200 kilometres east of Adelaide.

Windswept paddocks conceal the bones of livestock that have succumbed to the harsh conditions. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Louise runs the farm alongside her brother Tim, and the pair hasn't harvested a crop to sell at market for the past two years.

"We don't have a continuous cash flow coming in, we'd probably be better off going on the dole knowing you've got a cheque coming in every two weeks," she said.

"Never have we seen it this bad and this dry ... it's a part of history I never want to be part of again."

Now entering their third harvest season fruitless, they have sold almost all of their cattle and have halved their flock of sheep.

It is a decision taking a heavy mental toll.

Louise Smith has destocked her cattle from 350 to just 24 to maintain some income. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

"Many nights I have just sat there trying to sleep, but I'm thinking about where the next lot of feed will come from or planning the next load of sheep or cattle to go," she said.

" We are just winging it day-to-day praying it all falls into line. "

While some parts of South Australia are now expecting an average harvest after decent Spring rainfall, it is a different story for large parts of the Murraylands and Riverland region, which have not been so lucky.

The Maggea property has only received 106 millimetres of rain for the year. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

"[If] we were relying on cereal crops [this season], I don't think we would be here ... I'm pretty sure we wouldn't be here actually," Louise said.

Remaining cattle feed on grape marc as hay supply is scarce across the region. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

To get her farm and her family through, she has picked up extra work shearing sheep for farmers across the state.

She said it has been a lifeline for her financially and mentally.

"Going out to the shearing sheds has been a lifesaver for us because we're out talking to other farmers," she said.

Louise is just one of many women who are diversifying and trying to rise above the drought.

Healing through hardship

Suzie Evans is no stranger to isolation or prolonged drought conditions and knows more than most how hard life on the land can be.

She lost her son, Murray "Muzz" Chesser, to suicide seven years ago.

Her program, 'Workbench for the Mind', aims to support people while they wait for a GP appointment. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Through her grief, she found purpose and is now a mental health advocate, providing in-person workshops to those impacted by drought.

"We all have mental health, just like we have physical health," she said.

Suzie Evans says every farmer should take one per cent out of their day for themselves, which is 14 minutes. (ABC Rural: Jessica Schremmer)

A 2023 report on the mental health of the country's farmers revealed that almost half have had thoughts of self-harm or suicide.

Suzie feared the "pressure to keep farms going" for generations would hold many back from seeking help, but she urged them to do so.

Suzie Evans says a failed crop is a compounding factor on farmers' mental health. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Capturing the impact

Kiara Fisher is witnessing the mental and financial burden of the drought from her fifth-generation Bugle Hut family farm.

She noticed many people living in metropolitan areas were unaware that drought was still an issue in SA.

To try and raise national awareness online and bring the community together, she founded 'A Farmer's Plate' — a storytelling social media project.

Kiara Fisher's project aims to put a face to the farmers who are responsible for the food and fibre on supermarket shelves. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

"We want to achieve understanding, compassion and education of the general public," she said.

"I hope the general public will then have conversations with people that can help make change, so when [farmers] ask for help, they know they truly need it."

These mounds of sand used to be cropping paddocks. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

To capture the raw reality of people on the land, she connected with Riverland photographer and farmer's wife Rebecca Flack.

"I like to share the real elements of what we're going through with the drought," Rebecca said.

"Some of those pictures are quite graphic of animals, who unfortunately passed away, but that's a real visual."

Rebecca Flack says it's the first year her family is considering stopping farming. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

The duo said they have had an "overwhelming response".

"It's been comforting seeing farmers realise they're not the only ones going through a tough time and we are experiencing similar conditions," Rebecca said.

" We're all in this together. There is no such thing as a bad farmer. "

For many Mallee farmers, sand drift has been the biggest battle this season. (Supplied: Rebecca Flack)

Misconceptions of drought

These four rural women are all stepping up in their own way to highlight the challenges of farming in drought.

But they all agreed, the best support farmers could receive was understanding from people outside of their communities.

Louise Smith says interest-free loans for two years would help farmers get back on their feet. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Louise wants people to understand that some rain won't break a drought, and owning a farm does not always equate to wealth.

"A lot of city people think it's rained statewide, but there are still patches of the state that are struggling pretty badly," she said.

Kiara Fisher says many have spent money they don't have to get government assistance. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

Kiara agreed and said she was disappointed by the government's lack of understanding of what assistance would effectively help farmers through the drought.

"I think most farmers will say that their neighbours have done more for them this season than the government ever will," she said.

"The drought packages, look great on paper but for most people, spending money to get money back from the government is not a position they are in."

Minister for Primary Industries and Regional Development, Clare Scriven, said there has been "strong uptake" of the State Government’s drought support package with "just over $70 million distributed".

"More than 3,600 producers have been approved for money to assist them purchase equipment and other infrastructure ... including 749 producers in the Riverland, Murray and Mallee regions," she said in a statement.

Suzie Evans bought Wally after her son died, as it was his dream to have a Labrador. (ABC Riverland: Amelia Walters)

For Suzie Evans, she hopes more farmers can take that first step to seek support, even if it is just from a neighbour.

"We all need support, and we are all in this together; it's not a competition," she said.

title: Weeks before public outcry, Biosecurity Tasmania was worried about this horse stud
text:
Just weeks before a firestorm of public outrage erupted over conditions at a Tasmanian horse breeder's stud, an interdepartmental email was sent, revealing Biosecurity Tasmania feared it would become "our next significant animal/welfare issue".

In late September, Weona Park Stud, which is located in Tasmania's Southern Midlands and operates over two properties in Antill Ponds and Parattah, made headlines after photos of some of the horses were shared online.

Under Right to Information laws, the ABC has obtained a copy of an email dated September 2, 2025 from Biosecurity Tasmania investigators to the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE).

It was sent after an inspection of Weona Park Stud.

"This situation will continue and this property is likely to [be] the next welfare issue hitting the news, following on from harness racing horses with Yole and the Labradoodle case," the email said.

" The properties are so severely overstocked with horses, that its (sic) almost as if the horses are being feed lotted. "

The ABC understands at that time there were up to 250 horses being kept on the properties, with many in foal.

A Biosecurity Tasmania inspector described the properties as "severely overstocked with horses". (ABC News: Jess Moran)

The Biosecurity Tasmania report found there were several serious animal welfare issues at the property, and some round hay bales were at least three-years-old.

"I identified the major risk being welfare: overstocking, intensive yarding, horses exposed to high levels of manure, inadequate nutrition, no exercise, no shelter, no rugging, inadequate parasite treatment routine. There was not a single well-grown, well-presented strong yearling on the property," the report said.

"For such an untidy place, no overflowing bin with empty feed bags, no stack of feeding buckets near the feed supply area or in the yards."

Vet report raises serious concerns

The documents have also revealed a vet in Tasmania's north reported serious animal welfare concerns about the operation to the RSPCA and called for action to be taken.

Breeder agrees to rehome horses A Tasmanian horse breeder has agreed to reduce the number of horses on her property and rehome them, after concerns were raised by members of the racing community.

"The conditions at both properties fail to meet basic animal welfare standards … I am a veterinarian and have visited these sites professionally on multiple occasions," the vet said.

The vet, from the Meander Valley Veterinary Clinic, said on September 19, 2025, following two recent visits that month to the properties, they "observed a significant increase in the number of horses, despite already overstocked conditions".

"The excessive numbers and lack of space result in more frequent bullying, kicks, and bites," the vet said.

"This constant stress and physical conflict put the animals at a higher risk of injury and disease."

A vet visited the stud twice in September and raised several concerns. (ABC News: Jess Moran)

The vet said they had attempted to address these issues directly with the owners and employees and "believed they are trying to do the right thing with feed, veterinary care etc but simply do not think it can be done to an adequate standard [with] the sheer number of horses on the properties".

"My hope is that someone will conduct a formal and thorough assessment of these properties and work with the owners to improve the horses' living conditions," they said.

Weona Park Stud manager Fiona Methorst said feed sources had been improved and all horses have adequate feed and fresh water.

“A lot of people see no grass in the paddock and think that means no feed. This is far from the truth.

"We source a large quantity of round bales of hay and hard feed each year,” Ms Methorst said.

“Yes overcrowding is an issue but all horses have adequate feed and fresh water.

“We have since added exercise areas and equipment, along with the order of new shelters and stables back in July that are finally due for delivery this week.”

Years of complaints received

Between July 2011 and September 2025, the RSPCA received numerous animal welfare complaints about the breeder, raising concerns about stocking, feed and shelter.

"Too many horses for the size of the land," one complaint said.

Another said the horses were in "poor condition" in "overcrowded paddocks," while another complaint said "all horses are well fed and in great body condition" but "the concern is in relation to the amount of room they have to move around".

"A lot of manure in the paddocks which hasn't been removed, there is no shelter for these horses to get out of the weather," another complaint said.

The RSPCA said in a statement it triages calls that come through and forwards them to the agency with responsibility.

“Under our service agreement with NRE, the RSPCA operates a contact centre which houses the Animal Cruelty Helpline,” RSPCA chief executive Andrea Dawkins said.

"With the current complaints with Weona Park we are forwarding complaints to NRE as they are the lead investigators."

Andrea Dawkins says the RSPCA referred the case to NRE and the TasRacing Integrity Unit. (ABC News: Georgia Hogge)

Inspection finds horses emaciated, partially blind

The documents have also revealed the Antill Ponds property was the centre of an equine disease outbreak in 2023 with multiple horses experiencing "neurological clinical signs".

Equestrian Australia received controversial video weeks before probe Australia's peak body for equestrian sports received a controversial video of Olympic rider Heath Ryan appearing to whip a horse weeks before an investigation was commenced.

Inspection notes from July 2023 show several horses on the property were experiencing body and muscle weakness, one was emaciated, and another was found "down", and remained down despite food being offered.

Others had partial blindness, and deterioration in body condition.

In the report, the property was found to have no pasture and only had small areas of grass between some pens, there were too many horses on the property, and all pen walkways were muddy.

There was also a deficiency in vitamin E recorded. The report said this either demonstrated extreme malnutrition or a horse having two or more diseases or medical conditions at the same time.

"This owner should be required to consult a veterinarian for feeding instructions, an auditable chart to observe feeding protocol between visits, and regular visits to determine if feeding/husbandry requirements are being met," the report said.

"In addition, she should have licence removed as she is encouraged to buy more horses = profit, to cover costs of increased production (husbandry and feeding) costs."

The RSPCA received numerous animal welfare complaints about the breeder over a period of 14 years. (ABC News: Jess Moran)

The property was next inspected in November that year by officers from the Office of Racing Integrity and Biosecurity Tasmania.

Some mares were found to have overgrown hooves, not all horses had access to areas where they could exercise, feed and water was not consistent, and there was a deep layer of manure in most yards.
