"Water troughs must be kept clean and contain clean water at all times, horses should be allowed to exercise in a large yard or paddock for at least an hour every day, shade and shelter from wind and rain should be available in every yard and spoilt feed and manure should be removed from yards every day," the report said.

Rehoming efforts underway, owner says

In late September, following a multi-agency investigation sparked by the community outcry, stud manager Ms Methorst agreed the property was overstocked and said she would rehome around 100 horses, which she thought would take between three and six months.

So far, more than 40 horses have been rehomed and several are on a permanent lease agreement.

“I have had discussions with our vet team about the issue of concern which was overstocking,” Ms Methorst said.

“We have formulated a plan to downsize our stock and focus on our future goals.

"But we [are] currently and have been addressing all aspects to ensure quality horse welfare moving forward.

“I am pleased with the homes we have managed to get for these horses so far.

"There will be more available in the future for new homes but we are currently working on the younger horses in preparation for their next steps.

“As I said previously it will take time for this to happen and people need to understand that in the current market and economic climate it is hard to find so many suitable homes in a short timeframe."

title: The movie that pushed Rose Byrne to the edge of motherhood
text:
I hadn't planned on posing my curliest question to Sydney-born, New York-based star Rose Byrne straight off the bat. In fact, my notes clearly say: "Don't ask this first."

What: Motherhood as panic-attack inducing thriller that will also make you snort laugh Directed by: Mary Bronstein Starring: Rose Byrne, Danielle Macdonald, Delaney Quinn, A$AP Rocky, Christian Slater, Conan O'Brien, Ivy Wolk When: In cinemas November 13 Likely to make you feel: Like screaming into the void

But a bit like the absolute mayhem that follows a ceiling collapsing in a biblical flood, leaving a void in Linda's apartment — Linda being the harried mother Byrne plays in Mary Bronstein's second feature, If I Had Legs I'd Kick You – it just happened.

"What does the void mean to you, Rose?"

I've jumped ahead because a bright and breezy Byrne, white T-shirt glowing in New York's afternoon sun, is perched below an intricately painted floral ceiling. Like her spectacular lead performance, it simply cannot be ignored.

"Let's start with the easy ones," she says with a hearty guffaw, her Australian accent only occasionally twanging with adopted American intonations.

" The ceiling is the show-stopper. It's so funny, because someone said to me that it's like an existential birth canal. "

Funnily enough, in one trippy sequence, Linda stares up into the chasm and sees strange swirling lights that may or may not be there, spookily responding: "Mum?"

Byrne expands: "It's not not an existential birth canal, that's for sure. I live for the weirder aspects of filmmaking and the grey areas — the parts of being a person that are unexplainable."

"Mary definitely pushes the limits of that with this movie, which is very Lynchian," she says, referencing the late American filmmaker who created the weird and wonderful Twin Peaks.

Too many voices

Lynchian is a great way to sum up If I Had Legs I'd Kick You, which brilliantly functions on more than one level.

Sure, there are surreal moments, but on the surface, it's just a very bad day in the life of Linda.

Loading Instagram content

An exasperated therapist with enough of her own stuff going on at home, Linda can be brusque towards her clients. They include fellow US-based Australian actor Danielle Macdonald's clearly drowning new mum, Caroline.

"Danielle's is such a fantastic performance, embodying a woman in a deep, postpartum psychosis," Byrne says.

"It's heartbreaking, and Linda isn't helping."

That's partly because no-one is helping Linda.

Her husband (Christian Slater) is a captain away at sea, full of not-so-supportive suggestions on the phone while she struggles to single-handedly manage the health care of their persistently heard but almost-never-seen daughter (Delaney Quinn).

Linda is harangued by the beep of her daughter's feeding tube, connected to a mysterious ailment that's never named. She also has to battle with a snooty social worker (played by Bronstein) who constantly questions her medical choices.

At work, her colleague, who is also her therapist, is equally dismissive. Chat show host Conan O'Brien plays him in a chameleonic turn.

Talk-show royalty Conan O'Brien plays Linda's contemptuous therapist. (Supplied: A24)

"It's such a wink, because Conan's spent 20 years having someone in that chair, listening to, laughing at and indulging them," Byrne says.

"Then, in this, he actively has contempt for his patient, which is so funny, and Conan's razor-sharp wit shines through."

When the sky falls in, Linda's spiralling panic attack sees her and her daughter cooped up in a seedy motel.

In desperate need of peace, Linda's further frustrated by the pedant working at the front desk (Ivy Wolk), who refuses to sell her wine because ringing it up will creep past the licence.

So, Linda turns to rapper A$AP Rocky's motel manager for help with securing other means to dull her pain.

"Rocky fills the screen with charm, with that quality that you can't direct," Byrne says.

"You just have it, or you don't, and that brings relief to the audience. Suddenly, you can breathe."

And breathe

Breathing easy won't last in a film that's way more into hyperventilating.

Rose Byrne plays a mother on the edge in If I Had Legs I'd Kick You. (Supplied: Logan White / Courtesy of A24)

"The day-to-day minutia can tip you into the darkest part of your soul," Byrne, a mother of two, says.

" That's what makes the film so extraordinary and darkly funny — that tightrope comedy between the hugest questions and the tiniest little grievances. "

Everything from a screaming abandoned babe to a feral hamster on the loose to that gunk-raining chasm in her roof pushes Linda to her limits.

"Mary's vision was to ramp up this fever-pitch tension that adds up to a car crash, but you can't look away," Byrne says.

Bronstein told Byrne that no matter how wild Linda's responses to these rolling catastrophes get, we had to stay on her side.

"We might hate or be disgusted by her actions, but I said to Rose, 'The number one thing is, we love Linda'," Bronstein says.

"It doesn't work if there's no empathy."

Bronstein had complete trust in her star.

"When Rose came on, it became a movie," Bronstein says.

Mary Bronstein says Rose Byrne brings a certain depth to the role that couldn't have come from anyone else. (Supplied: A24)

"She's a true creative partner. She's a serious theatre actor who's played Medea, and she's a gifted comedian as well.

"I was given a gift to have her talent."

A career with legs

Byrne grew up in Balmain and cut her teeth in the movie Dallas Doll alongside Sandra Bernhard and Two Hands with the late Heath Ledger.

"We were just kids starting out, and it's beyond my wildest dreams I'm still doing it," Byrne says.

"More and more, it feels like a miracle, what with AI, and I have so many friends who are out-of-work crew members."

As Bridesmaids star Byrne sees it, comedy kicked her career into high gear.

"It was a huge creative turning point," Byrne says.

"It felt freeing, and also more challenging. Something I can really sink my teeth into."

Rose Byrne and Heath Ledger take a break from celebrating Two Hands at the Sundance Film Festival in 1999. (Lindsay Brice / Getty Images)

For every excruciating moment in If I Had Legs I'd Kick You, there’s a laugh-out-loud chaser.

Debuting at Sundance in January, it went on to the Berlin International Film Festival, where Byrne was awarded the Silver Bear for Best Leading Performance. There's already Oscars buzz.

"It's very surreal, because I've never been in this conversation," Byrne says.

"Of course it's flattering, and I'm as vulnerable as the next person in this business. But I've also realised it's out of my hands. I'm just honoured to be part of the conversation."

Laughing at herself as much as anyone else allows me to end on a slightly cheekier note. Is Bobby Cannavale — who also starred in Medea — a more supportive husband than the frankly useless one played by Slater?

"That's not cheeky at all," Byrne says, with a hearty chuckle. "Bobby's hyper-present, completely engaged."

If I Had Legs I'd Kick You is in cinemas now.

title: Rain a relief but Victorian drought 'certainly not over'
text:
Soaking rain has brought relief to dry paddocks across Victoria, but it will take months or even years for farmers to recover from the drought.

After a dry start to spring, the rain clouds rolled in during October and early November, bringing widespread falls.

Much of Victoria has been in drought for the past two years, but it has been particularly tough in the south-west of the state.

Colac dairy farmer and president of Dairy Farmers Victoria Mark Billing said his farm had been transformed by the rain.

"I've never seen a change around so quickly. Six weeks ago we were on a knife's edge," he said.

Before: Jason Smith's farm in south-west Victoria in April. . . After: The same farm after the rain in October. . . Instructions: Use left and right arrow keys to control image transition Before and after images SLIDE Jason Smith's farm in south-west Victoria in April. / The same farm after the rain in October.

Barren to bogged

Before the rain, Mr Billing had to re-sow his pasture because earlier plantings did not survive.

"Now I'm sitting in a paddock of oats that's been cut for silage. I'm 6 foot 3 and it's up to my waist.

"We've got feed coming out of our ears. We've gone from famine to feast for the cows, which is absolutely awesome," Mr Billing said.

He has had so much rain that his car got bogged in a paddock.

"That's an embarrassing thing … but it's a nice place to be at the moment," he laughed.

Mark Billing's car got bogged because it is so wet. (Supplied: Mark Billing)

Late break

It is a similar story in Gippsland, where paddocks are now lush.

Ian Hooker received 75 millimetres on his dairy farm at Loch in South Gippsland this week in what he described as "a spring turn-around".

"It was getting pretty desperate (before this rain), our dams were near enough on stumps," he said.

"All the fodder was gone, we used it all and had to buy a few loads, which is very expensive and took the profit out of the job.

"I reckon if we keep getting follow up rains over the next couple of months we'll end up doing alright."

South Gippsland farmers are enjoying good pasture and dams filling up. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Drought 'not over'

Agriculture Victoria seasonal risk agronomist Dale Grey said the recent rain had been welcome.

"We're seeing enough rainfall to keep the soil moisture damp in the surface, and keep pastures and crops growing really well.

"It should be good grass growth now around the state right up until mid-December, which is not what it was looking like [a few months ago]," he said.

But Mr Grey said there is "not a lot (of moisture) left underneath those plants and crops".

" The drought is certainly not over. "

Dale Grey says Victorian farmers are not out of the woods yet. (ABC Rural: Annie Brown)

'Tough year' continuing in the north

Farmers in the north-west have not been as fortunate with the rain this spring.

Dale Ramsay farms in Werrimull, south-west of Mildura, and he has received about half his average annual falls.

"It's probably around 110 millimetres compared with an average of about 230 millimetres.

Millewa farmer Dale Ramsay searches the sky for rain. (ABC News: Timu King)

"It's been a tough year with no sheep feed, and we've gone through a lot of hay and grain to maintain the flock.

"(But) with the low rainfall, we're grateful for the crops we've got … and hopefully next year things will get back on track."

Counting the financial cost

Back near Colac, farmer Jason Smith is dealing with paddocks that are too wet.

"But I'm not complaining," he said.

"In April-May, I had a thousand acres without a blade of grass on it … it looked like the moon."

"Now there's feed in every paddock."

But Mr Smith said the effects of drought will last for a long time.

"I've got debt levels for hay purchasing, and I've got forward contracts for palm kernel and such that I don't need anymore.

"There is those sort of hang-overs that we'll have to catch-up with," he said.

Mark Billing's dairy cows have plenty of feed now. (Supplied: Mark Billing)

Mr Billing agrees, saying that cash flow on farms is still "really tight".

"The effects of the drought as far as the on-farm physical part of it is recovering.

"But the financial implications of the drought is still going to be hanging over us for quite a while," he said.

Additional reporting by Faith Tabalujan and Timu King.

title: Survival-inspired camping is the ultimate challenge — how long would you last?
text:
Figuring out what 18-year-old Rivi can leave behind when he goes camping in Tasmania's wilderness has been as important as knowing what to take.

It has been a gradual process — first, starting out with short trips and then slowly building up to longer stays.

"In our packs, we carry a first aid kit, sleeping bags, a shovel, ropes, canned food, and water. No tents, only a tarp in case it rains," Rivi said.

Jump to the Survival Camping Quiz

He also carries a satellite phone to contact his parents, who were hesitant at first but have come to trust his skills and judgement.

While camping, Rivi said respecting the environment came first — leave the forest as its found and carefully return any fallen trees used for shelter. (Supplied)

The Tasmanian terrain is known for its harsh elements, so much so, its West Coast Range was chosen to test contestants on SBS's survival reality show, Alone Australia.

But Rivi's love for survival-inspired camping didn't come from TV — it began on a camping trip with his friend Harrison.

The pair went hiking deep in the forest, which meant carrying only the essentials.

Originally from Gampaha, Sri Lanka, Rivi didn’t grow up camping, but he hopes to join the Defence Force after falling in love with Australia’s wilderness. (ABC News: Marc Eiden)

"Because we were walking over an hour into the forest, we had to get rid of a lot of gear — that's when it changed to 'survival mode,'" Rivi said.

For Rivi, it is less about exploring the area and more about creating a temporary home off the main tracks, sitting in silence, and putting his problem-solving skills to the test as conditions change.

"The more I'm away from my phone and distractions, the more I'm connected to what matters," he said.

" I've realised that the more I seek discomfort, the more comfortable I feel in myself. It's also taught me to be more confident. "

Before you explore Tasmania's parks and reserves Entry to all national parks require a valid pass

Light fires only in designated pits or zones. Extra bans apply during fire-danger periods

Don't feed, harm, or remove protected wildlife or plants

Pack clothing and equipment for changeable weather

Let someone know your plans — they should call triple-0 if you don't return at a set time

Carry a Personal Locator Beacon (PLB) in remote areas

When Rivi and his family arrived in Tasmania two years ago, it was the middle of a winter night in August.

Originally from Gampaha, a city 40 minutes from Sri Lanka's capital, Colombo, 18-year-old Rivi found that his new home in Burnie, Tasmania, looked nothing like the place he had grown up.

Refining the necessities in his pack was a slow, methodical process for Rivi, with safety always at the forefront. (ABC News: Marc Eiden)

With the coast on one side and thick bush and mountains on the other, Rivi never imagined this would become home, or that he would forge such a strong connection to the land through survival-style camping.

"When I first moved to Australia, I felt separated from my home, my family, my friends and everything I knew," he said.

"But in the landscape of my new Australian home, camping has given me a new kind of connection."

Have fun but know your limits and be prepared, expert warns

Alex Mileham, founder of Survival Courses Tasmania, has spent 35 years hiking and camping solo across the world. (Supplied)

Alex Mileham has spent 35 years hiking and practising survival alone around the world, and he says the real danger is often closer than people expect.

He says that, unlike Rivi, survival camping is not always a choice, and most people getting caught out were underprepared and did not have the right skills.

"The most likely scenario for a real-life survival situation is often day hikers," he said.

"Because they think that by nine o'clock at night, they're going to be back on the couch with a pizza or something, so they go unprepared and overconfident."

There are rules to follow when using Tasmania's national parks. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Mr Mileham is the founder of Survival Courses Tasmania and teaches survival and bushcraft skills to people from all walks of life, including surgeons, teachers, mechanics, and psychologists.

Half of his students are women.

"Some of the women who have done my courses are part of a hiking group, and they want to venture out on their own," he said.

"I teach how to build your self-confidence and your resilience in those situations in the bush."

Mr Mileham grew up hiking the Brecon Beacons in Wales, a mountainous region bordering England, which has been used for SAS training for years.

By 14, he was testing survival skills alone, and at 25 he completed his first solo trek in Nepal. He has also trained with survival experts, the UK's Ray Mears and Australia's Bob Cooper.

Mr Mileham says it's most likely day trekkers that get caught out in changing conditions without the right gear. (ABC News: Jano Gibson)

He stressed that Tasmania's weather was unpredictable and changed quickly, with mistakes happening fast if people became disorientated and began to panic.

"You can start off on a hike in lovely weather, wearing lightweight clothing and it can just change," he said.

"If you're wet, there's wind, and you're cold, those three things are almost guaranteed to bring on hypothermia when combined.

"At least with a multi-day hike, you're probably better prepared, because you're planning to spend the night or more."

In October, Tasmania's wilderness claimed the life of bushwalker Daryl Fong and has prompted numerous rescue operations, with a 76-year-old man still missing in Tasmanian bushland.

"I encourage everybody to go out and have fun, but be prepared with the right clothing and equipment, and ideally some training … because nature will always defeat you if you're overconfident," Mr Mileham said.

Test your instincts with this survival-inspired quiz

title: 'We can't retire yet — or ever': NDIS uncertainty up-ending families
text:
While most couples in their 60s are planning for retirement, Louise and Darren Catton have been preparing for the day they can no longer care for their 22-year-old daughter, Mary.

The Caboolture couple has spent years curating a care plan for Mary, who is non-verbal, that accommodates for her cerebral palsy, epilepsy, mobility issues and autism.

But Ms Catton said their plans were up-ended earlier this year when they received notice that Mary's National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) care plan would be cut dramatically.

Ms Catton is 60, while her husband is 63.

The Cattons discovered in August that Mary's annual NDIS funding would be cut by almost $250,000. (Supplied: Louise Catton)

"As we got older, we needed to set Mary up as best we could so she could live her life as independently as possible from us," Ms Catton said.

" We know that we can't retire just yet, or maybe ever, because now we don't know what the future holds. "

While the NDIS says adjustments to plans are carefully made to suit each participant's needs, disability advocates believe Mary's case is a drop in the "tsunami of cuts" to plans being experienced across the country.

Funding cut threatens overnight care

In a decision that has since been reviewed by the NDIS, the Cattons discovered in August that Mary's annual NDIS funding would be cut by almost $250,000.

Mary's care plan included one-on-one, around-the-clock care from a support worker, with two support workers periodically assigned to help take her to appointments or to socialise.

The Cattons requested the NDIS carry out an internal review of Mary's case. (Supplied: Louise Catton)

The family said the looming funding cut meant they may not be able to afford overnight care and allied health services for Mary, and threatened the removal of two-on-one community access support.

"With her uncontrolled epilepsy now, she needs two staff to safely support her outside of her home," Ms Catton said.

"If she has a seizure, we need two staff. If she has a meltdown, she needs two staff … she can become aggressive because of anxiety."

The Caboolture couple has spent years curating a care plan for Mary. (Supplied: Louise Catton)

In a statement, a spokesperson for the National Disability Insurance Agency said its priority was to ensure every participant had access to the services they required.

"Participant support needs may go up and down," the spokesperson said.

"Providing time for a gradual adjustment to any changes to current supports ensures this is done carefully over time, with a focus on maintaining the needs of participants while building their capacity."

Process takes a toll

The Cattons requested the NDIS carry out an internal review of Mary's case, which this week saw her funding increased by almost $70,000 — but not restored to its previous amount.

"We should not have had to have made the number of complaints we did to be heard," Ms Catton said.

Ms Catton said the internal review process had taken a toll on the family.

Ms Catton is concerned she may have to fight for her daughter's funding each year. (ABC News: Lucy Loram)

Mary is the youngest of four children. Her older siblings are Emily, 30, Oliver, 27, and Grace, 25.

"Mary became so depressed that she was sobbing through the night due to the cuts that the NDIS made back in August," she said.

"Is the expectation that Darren and I have to mount this battle every single year? Are they going to be looking at cutting her funding every time even though nothing is changing?"

'Tsunami of cuts' to plans

Matilda Alexander, a human rights lawyer and chief executive of Queensland Advocacy for Inclusion, said the number of NDIS recipients reaching out for help to review their funding cuts was increasing.

"This is a very worrying trend. We're seeing a real tsunami of cuts to plans," Ms Alexander said.

"This has huge implications on day-to-day living and the ability to keep trusted long-term workers engaged in support employment."

Family fears NDIS review could cut 'essential' exercise therapy Leo depends on exercise physiology to keep him moving, but there are fears that could change under an NDIS review.

Ms Alexander said NDIS participants and families should feel empowered to ask for both internal and tribunal reviews.

"It's very hard to find lawyers and advocates who have capacity to help because we are just overloaded with this case work at the moment," she said.

"But do try and seek help … a lot of these decisions are actually being overturned."

Data from the Administrative Review Tribunal found 80 per cent of reviews into NDIS plans resulted in overturned decisions.

Support coordinator Kylie Lamb, who manages the specialist services that Mary used, said significant reductions in funding risked jeopardising a participant's progress.

With uncontrolled epilepsy, Mary needs two staff to safely support her outside of her home. (Supplied: Louise Catton)

"The Mary that I started working with in 2021, to the Mary that I supported in 2025, is night and day — but that does not mean that her disability has stopped being complex," Ms Lamb said.

"It just means that probably for the first time in her life she had the most appropriate level of support for her disability."

title: Gold Coast Schoolies celebrations set to be scaled back and subdued
text:
Schoolies celebrations on the Gold Coast will be scaled back for the first time this year due to ongoing beach erosion in the wake of Tropical Cyclone Alfred.

The state government and Gold Coast Council have confirmed graduates will still be able to party on the beach when celebrations kick off next weekend, November 22.

However, the schoolies hub — which is a dedicated alcohol-free and drug-free entertainment precinct, set up on the Surfers Paradise beachfront — will be smaller than previous years due to safety concerns.

"The department has been working closely with the City of Gold Coast on the best location for the Schoolies Hub," a Queensland government spokesperson said.

"On advice from council's coastal experts, event infrastructure [including the stage] will be located off the sand.

"The safety of young people and the local community remains the highest priority."

A smaller section of Surfers Paradise Beach will be cordoned off for the Schoolies hub (right) compared to previous years (left). (Supplied: Schoolies GC)

'Fitness for fun'

The first Schoolies run club will also be held this year to cater for the growing proportion of school leavers trading hangovers for wholesome daytime activities.

Red Frogs founder and director Andy Gourley said there had been a "dramatic change" in the culture over the past five years.

"The key indicator to us were the cafes. The cafes at Surfers were empty back in the day — tumbleweeds going through them," Mr Gourley said.

Andy says there has been a dramatic shift in drinking habits. (Supplied: National Australia Day Council)

" But now, come 9-10 in the morning, they're just full of schoolies doing smashed avo and lattes. "

He said schoolies were also focused on their health and fitness, consuming less alcohol than previous years.

"We see about probably half of schoolies aren't big drinkers now and they're more interested in their fitness and sport so, this year, we've got some run clubs we're setting up to do, and also we'll jump into a bit of morning yoga with them as well," Mr Gourley said.

"If we can wear them out during the day, that means less dramas at night-time."

The first Schoolies run club will be held on the Gold Coast. (Getty Images/Warren Little)

Why the shift?

Gold Coast-based GP and Bond University assistant professor Kieran Le Plastrier said generation Alpha and Z were some of the lowest alcohol consumers in the history of Western culture.

"Their initiation to alcohol is much later, the risk of binge-drinking is much lower and all drug use in that group of people is actually much, much lower," Dr Le Plastrier said.

The stage will be set up off the sand. (ABC Gold Coast: Kimberley Bernard)

"This is a group of humans which have had the benefits since they were children of understanding the risks and harms, and so a lot of young people actually don't want to drink excessively because they actually know the damage that it's doing to their bodies and to their brains."

He urged schoolies wanting to consume alcohol to pace themselves and to ensure they had plenty of water to drink and food to eat.

"Make sure you're not drinking alone and if you see your friend obviously becoming intoxicated, it's really time to stop drinking, get the water into them, get them a bit of ibuprofen and get them home for a sleep," Dr Le Plastrier said.

Plenty of space to party

Mayor Tom Tate says beach restoration works are continuing. (ABC Gold Coast: Steve Keen)

Schoolies beach parties were in limbo after Cyclone Alfred ripped an estimated 6 million cubic metres of sand from beaches across the city in March.

Since then, the Gold Coast Council has spent about $35 million to get the beaches back to a suitable condition, with 1 million cubic metres of sand dredged and pumped towards the shoreline.

Mayor Tom Tate said there would be ample space to host an estimated 15,000 teenage school leavers, especially with the closure of the Surfers Paradise Esplanade to traffic for a three-month trial.

title: Sixers teenager left shocked after claiming WBBL hat-trick
text:
Sydney Sixers rising star Caoimhe Bray needed to be told she had claimed a hat-trick, as the 16-year-old added another WBBL highlight in a thumping derby defeat of the Thunder.

Bray took her wickets across two overs, the third thanks to a fantastic diving catch at point from Erin Burns.

The excitement of that wicket may have been to blame for Bray and her teammates not knowing she had completed a hat-trick.

They were all shocked to hear of the feat when the ground announcer informed the crowd over the speakers.

Bray finished with 4-15 from her four overs, helping the Sixers record a 24-run win over the Thunder at Sydney's Drummoyne Oval on Saturday night.

"It's pretty crazy … I didn't realise," said Bray, who is also the Junior Matildas goalkeeper.

"It was one of those weird ones that was at the end of the over."

Maitlan Brown (2-18) was also effective on a night that favoured the bowlers.

But the Sixers will wait on scans for New Zealand all-rounder Amelia Kerr, who injured her quad in the warm-up and was forced out of the match.

The Sixers had Sophie Dunkley (43 off 35) and Mady Villiers (24 not out) to thank for scraping together their total of 9-142, while Alyssa Healy (26 off 15) threatened to explode.

But the Thunder's star-studded batting order failed to fire in reply, with 18-year-old debutante Lucy Finn (49 not out off 34 balls) valiant in a losing cause after her side had fallen to 7-49.

The Thunder finished their 20 overs on 8-118.

In Saturday's earlier match at Drummoyne Oval, the Hobart Hurricanes posted a 16-run win over the Brisbane Heat via the DLS method.

title: The Brisbane restaurants that will restore your faith in yum cha
text:
Advertisement

Eating outFood The Brisbane restaurants that will restore your faith in yum cha Yum cha isn’t what it used to be, but these restaurants are offering innovative menus to keep the tradition alive – with or without the trolleys. Matt Shea November 16, 2025 Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share

Yum cha has changed. That’s the first thing you need to know when considering where to head for some leisurely Sunday dim sum. The sprawling suburban joints with the powered trolleys? They’re few and far between these days. Instead, if a restaurant is peddling a yum cha menu, it will usually be a tiered-price menu that’s a variation on an a la carte menu, or a banquet menu that presents a number of dishes (perhaps bottomless, within reason) for a set price. Supernormal is serving a special dumplings menu on Sundays. Markus Ravik Southside and Central executive chef Benny Lam remembers yum cha quickly becoming part of his Brisbane childhood after he moved with his family from Hong Kong in 1992. “My uncle had a Chinese restaurant in Capalaba,” Lam says. “Every Monday was his day off so he would go to Chinatown [in Fortitude Valley] to buy groceries and have a bit of yum cha.

Advertisement

Related Article Perspective Restaurants open in Brisbane until 2am? Why not? “Back then, it was the Chinese chef tradition to go to Chinatown on Mondays because the daytime would be so quiet at their restaurants. So you’d go in, and it had this really good vibe because you would see everyone and talk about this and that.” Lam reckons yum cha isn’t what it used to be for two reasons. First, fresh dim sum is hard. “Because dumplings are handmade, you need to have a large restaurant and a super high volume to make it sustainable. Even a restaurant like Southside – if we did just yum cha, we’d 100 per cent have to close in a few months.”

Advertisement

“It was the Chinese chef tradition to go to Chinatown on Mondays … it had this really good vibe because you would see everyone and talk about this and that.” Southside and Central executive chef Benny Lam. But also, fresh dim sum is popular, and long ago became part of the everyday a la carte menu at upmarket Chinese and pan-Asian restaurants, meaning the need for yum cha-focused restaurants – or a yum cha service in those restaurants – fell away. Those that remain are a bit hit or miss. The economies of scale Lam talks about mean a lot of restaurants are ordering their dim sum wholesale, rather than making it fresh themselves. Everyone has an underwhelming yum cha story. The following list is not that. Here’s where to get your yum cha fix in Brisbane. Southside

Advertisement

South Brisbane east Asian restaurant Southside recently revised its yum cha menu, which kicks off at noon every Sunday. Southside runs its yum cha menu every Sunday. Markus Ravik It features a la carte menu dishes alongside signature yum cha items, such as goldfish prawn dumplings with tobiko, and panfried pork gyoza with a dan dan sauce and vinegar caramel. The menu is priced at $59 without drinks, or $99 with a two-hour beverage package that throws in house wines, tap beer and signature cocktails. Where to enjoy it? Outside, in the restaurant’s bucolic fern garden beneath the train overpass is best. 63 Melbourne Street, South Brisbane, southside-restaurant.com.au

Advertisement

Ru Yi Dim Sum A bunch of top Brisbane chefs will happily chew your ear off about Ru Yi – Lam, Stanley’s Louis Tikaram, and The Fifty Six’s Gerald Ong among them. This is closer to the traditional yum cha experience, but with the trolley replaced by an extensive sub-menu of dim sum, tiered in price. Dishes range from a wide variety of dumplings (prawn and chive, prawn and water chestnut, assorted mushroom, to name a few) to pork buns, steamed chicken feet with signature sauce, congee, and rice noodle rolls. Related Article One of West End’s best small restaurants has closed permanently Everything is housemade, meaning the dumplings are fresh and precisely executed.

Advertisement

Don’t be put off by the location within Calamvale Central shopping centre: the restaurant itself is a charming, comfortable little space in which to spend an hour or two. Just be sure to book because this place absolutely pumps most services. Shop 59/662 Compton Road, Calamvale, ruyidimsum.com.au Longwang This slick CBD diner from Tassis Group bills itself as pan-Asian, but Cantonese is the cornerstone of Longwang’s cuisine so it leans hard into yum cha over summer, 11am-4pm on Friday and Saturday, and all day on Sunday. CBD restaurant Longwang will kick off a new yum cha menu in December. Markus Ravik

Advertisement

Named Yum Cha Cha Cha, the menu features dishes such as natural oysters; a beef tartare bite with chilli kosho, chives and tobiko; a wagyu beef dumpling in a beef broth with chilli oil; and XO prawn toast. For drinks, there are wines by Counterpoint and house beers on tap, but you can add cocktail jugs or a premium drinks upgrade. Yum Cha Cha Cha runs from December 15 to January 31 and is $68 per diner for a 90-minute sitting, or $78 per person for a two-hour sitting. 144 Edward Street, Brisbane, longwang.com.au Landmark Sunnybank These huge yum cha spots arguably aren’t what they used to be, but Landmark Sunnybank remains an institution in the southern suburbs, and at busy times, at least, you’ll get some trolley action.

Advertisement

Landmark in Sunnybank is a perennial favourite with yum cha tragics. Robert Shakespeare Expect a yum cha menu with tiered pricing and dishes such as steamed spare ribs in black bean sauce, Shanghai pork dumplings, and steamed custard buns, along with barbecue dishes and seafood. Just don’t leave your visit too late on the weekend – this place is immensely popular. Golden Lane, in the same centre, is also worth a shout-out. 101/358 Mains Rd, Sunnybank, landmarkrestaurant.com.au Goodtime

Advertisement

This neatly designed little restaurant has quietly developed a loyal local following since opening in one of the old warehouse spaces in West Village in September 2024. Related Article Lion to permanently close Stone & Wood brewpub Monday to Thursday it presents its dim sum items as a banquet menu priced at $29 with any drinks order, or $69 with bottomless drinks. Dishes include pork xiao long bao, crispy pork gyoza, chicken siu mai, salt and pepper chicken, and crispy fried squid with salt and pepper. Shop T22/45 Mollison Street, West End, goodtimecheers.com

Advertisement

Stanley Stanley runs a yum cha menu every lunch Monday to Saturday, but on Sundays from 11.30am it becomes more of an event with a yum cha banquet for $59, or a champagne option for $158, and DJs spinning on the restaurant’s riverside deck. Stanley turns its lunchtime yum cha into an event on Sundays. The menu includes dishes such as prawn and chive spring rolls; Moreton Bay bug spring rolls; steamed barbecue pork buns with chilli jam; and pork and prawn dumplings served with either an aromatic broth or spicy sichuan with peanut and sesame. The champagne package adds two hours of free-flowing Louis Roederer.

Advertisement

5 Boundary Street, Brisbane, stanleyrestaurant.com.au Yum Cha Garden City This handsome spot in the Westfield Mount Gravatt dining precinct presents its yum cha menu as a one-hour all-you-can-eat (with a drink purchase) deal, with prices for adults $59 during the week and $69 from Friday to Sunday and on public holidays. Related Article Brisbane’s best sandwiches? Here are our top picks of the past year Expect the yum cha classics, from pork and shrimp siu mai and barbecue pork buns through to crispy skin chicken and a variety of cheung fun. There’s also a premium section limited to one order per diner – think steamed scallops in garlic sauce, crispy roast duck, and black truffle fried rice.

Advertisement

The fitout is a modern interpretation of a classic Chinese restaurant, with parquet floors, white table linen and red and mirrored features, making it a neat place to dwell over some dim sum. Shop R6, Westfield Mount Gravatt, Cnr Logan and Kessels Road, Upper Mount Gravatt, yumchagc.com.au Supernormal A modern yum cha offering in all but name, every Sunday from 11.30am this riverside blockbuster looks not to just Hong Kong and China, but also Korea and Japan, for a tight menu of dim sum that changes weekly. Supernormal’s Sunday dumpling menu changes weekly.

Advertisement

Check the restaurant’s website to find out what’s on that week but expect dishes such as Moreton Bay bug toast; vegetable dumplings with shiitake XO; prawn and chicken dumplings with chilli vinegar; barbecue pork buns; and oxtail dumplings with red radish and orange. All are priced to be ordered individually to keep things approachable and flexible, and the a la carte menu is still available. In conjunction with the yum cha menu, the bar is stirring a tight, seasonal selection of chuhai highballs. 443 Queen Street, Brisbane, brisbane.supernormal.net.au Donna Chang This beautiful CBD restaurant feels tailor-made for a leisurely Sunday gathering, and Donna Chang has addressed that with a yum cha banquet menu.

Advertisement

Related Article Where to find Brisbane’s best ramen There are three variations: standard, pescatarian and non-pescatarian. Expect dishes such as pork xiao long bao; Moreton Bay bug dumplings; chicken, prawn and shiitake siu mai; cumin-spiced lamb buns; prawn and wombok gyoza; and a sesame prawn toast with a seaweed mayo. Donna Chang’s yum cha runs every Sunday 10am-12pm. Suite 3/171 George Street, Brisbane, donnachang.com.au

Restaurant reviews, news and the hottest openings served to your inbox. Sign up

Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Share License this article More: Food

For subscribers Matt Shea is Food and Culture Editor at Brisbane Times. He is a former editor and editor-at-large at Broadsheet Brisbane, and has written for Escape, Qantas Magazine, the Guardian, Jetstar Magazine and SilverKris, among many others.

title: We are addicted to fossil fuels, so let’s just accept it
text:
Suggesting that fossil fuels will stay around for a long time remains taboo in the energy debate. In climate change gatherings, the world has agreed to “consign coal to history” and “transition away” from oil and natural gas.

It has signalled, too, “the beginning of the end” of the fossil-fuel era and a “swift” transition to renewables.

That’s all very well meaning, but there’s a problem: With apologies to Margaret Thatcher, fossil fuels are not for turning.

The main long-term influence is the global push to reduce carbon emissions. Credit: AP

Just two years ago, the International Energy Agency (IEA) unequivocally said that fossil-fuel demand would peak before the end of this decade. It was a black-and-white statement that left no wiggle room.

title: It took 20 years to convince her to take this role – was it worth the wait?
text:
MUSIC

Cocteau’s Circle ★★★★

Australian Chamber Orchestra, Melbourne Recital Centre, November 15 “Astonish me!” This striking command drove the work of French poet and artistic polymath Jean Cocteau, after he was challenged by legendary Russian ballet impresario Sergei Diaghilev. In the years following World War I, Cocteau became associated with a remarkable number of painters, writers and most importantly, musicians. His collaborations with composers such as Stravinsky, Satie, Poulenc and Honegger certainly did yield astonishing results. Le Gateau Chocolat performs in Cocteau’s Circle with the Australian Chamber Orchestra. Credit: Daniel Boud In paying homage to Cocteau’s remarkable legacy, the Australian Chamber Orchestra has chosen to celebrate it in truly contemporary fashion. Set in a smoky, would-be cabaret, Cocteau’s spirit speaks through Le Gateau Chocolat, whose combination of deep bass voice, gender-bending costumes and outré stage presence reinterpret the libertine ambience of interwar Paris for our own times. Richard Tognetti and the ACO enthusiastically lead the audience on a 90-minute musical odyssey through scores associated with Cocteau, interspersed with empathetic connective tissue commissioned from Elena Kats-Chernin.

Australian-born, German-based soprano Chloe Lankshear adds a classy vocal element, including a nostalgic sung waltz by Poulenc and Lili Boulanger’s plangent Pie Jesu, before finishing with a husky, impassioned account of Edith Piaf’s Hymn to Love. Melbourne pianist Stefan Cassomenos dashes off some pianistic pyrotechnics from Jean Francaix’s Concertino for Piano and Orchestra with customary aplomb. Loading Movements from string quartets by Ravel and Debussy arranged for the orchestra elicit the ACO’s habitual verve, as does Darius Milhaud’s Le boeuf sur le toit, named for the bar where Cocteau’s set used to hang out. Le Gateau Chocolat’s glitteringly camp but heartfelt vocal contributions range from Gershwin to, of all things, Janis Ian’s 1970s hit Stars. While perhaps not astonishing, this thoughtful, colourful tribute to one of last century’s most precocious artistic minds does have an appropriate sense of pushing boundaries, just as the ACO has done over its 50 years of existence.

Reviewed by Tony Way

MUSIC

Sam Fender | People Watching Tour ★★★★

Sidney Myer Music Bowl, November 14 The brisk cold of a Melbourne spring evening doesn’t thwart the crowd’s enthusiasm at Sidney Myer Music Bowl. Some in the seated section have already left their allocated spots to surround the front of the stage. When the lights dim, fans roar at Sam Fender and his band’s arrival. Sam Fender performs at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl on November 14. Credit: Paul Rovere The 31-year-old English singer-songwriter from North Shields has sold out arenas across the UK, Ireland, Europe and North America. He recently won the Mercury Prize for his 2025 album People Watching – awarded to musicians from the UK and Ireland for best album – and donated the winnings to the Music Venues Trust, a charity that preserves small live performance venues. Fender is accompanied by a seven-piece band filled with multi-instrumentalists, including drums, guitar, keys, back-up vocals, tambourine, saxophone and trumpet. When they all perform together, the sound inside the bowl is so electric you can feel the pulsating rhythm in your body; getting lost in the music, you forget where you are.

Despite confessing that he’s suffering from jet lag, Fender’s performance never falters. “All right, let’s do this, lads,” he says as he launches into Will We Talk? His repertoire is a mix of slower tracks and American-style 1970s rock ballads. Talk to You, a collaboration featuring Elton John on piano on the original track, is sung with an air of regret about the end of a long-term friendship. Spit of You seeps with a pleading tone as he sings about the fraught communication between a father and son; a Polaroid appears of him and his father on screen. Fender’s Melbourne performance never faltered. Credit: Paul Rovere Contrastingly, the album’s title track People Watching feels anthemic and Crumbling Empire is reminiscent of the Killers’ heartland rock era, with visuals of mountain ranges, desert landscapes and industrial plants playing into the working-class sensibility. Howdon Aldi Death Queue is a fun punk rock interlude, which Fender jokingly describes as “the stupidest song I ever wrote”. Seventeen Going Under is a highlight. Fender demands that the crowd sings along, and they abide enthusiastically. The keyboard player stands on his seat and amps up fans as the drums pound and trumpet and saxophone soar. Fender makes fun of the pretence of leaving the stage before an encore, and the crowd continues the vocal riff to coax him back. “Melbourne, thank you so much for a wonderful f---ing night,” Fender shouts. With a bang, white confetti fills the air, followed by deafening guitar and cheers.

Reviewed by Vyshnavee Wijekumar

PERFORMANCE

Guewel ★★★

Arts House, until November 16 A guewel is a West African oral historian, someone who carries in memory the stories of local families, who can summon the lore of a place and its people as a celebratory recitation. Guewel at Arts House. Credit: Gregory Lorenzutti In this hour-long production led by Lamine Sonko, the figure of the guewel is reimagined as a conduit between earthly rhythms and the life of the stars: the custodian of a larger lore. The show sketches the outlines of a cosmology, while also showcasing a cohort of gifted performers – dancers, musicians, ritualists – in front of lushly animated projections.

At its centre are three figures personifying the sun, the moon and the stars. Their full-body costumes – gorgeously sculptural – recall masquerades from Senegal’s Casamance region, with their all-enveloping silhouettes. The dried fronds and towering crest of the figure representing the stars suggest a Kumpo-like apparition, while the moon reads as a delicate crescent, with cowrie shells gleaming on dark cloth. The voltage that runs through Guewel comes from the drumming and dancing. Credit: Gregory Lorenzutti The costumes are impressive, but the voltage that runs through Guewel comes from the drumming and dancing. Hand-drum flurries launch sudden accelerations; legs carve lateral pathways as the dancers kick up their heels. The animations are often beautiful, with veils and translucencies, but at times the smoky effects pull focus from bodies onstage. The visual busyness dilutes the intimacy.

Still, it’s the projections that spell out the work’s big ideas: everything is interwoven, nature moves in cycles. The cosmology is legible, even when dramaturgical transitions feel more ceremonial than exploratory. The figure representing the stars in Guewel, who harks back to West African masquerades. Credit: Gregory Lorenzutti What does it mean to really inhabit ancestral knowledge, not just cite it? Brief as it is, Guewel cannot offer a full answer. It plays more like a prelude that clears space for a deeper encounter. Seven years in gestation and framed as a cross-cultural collaboration, Guewel feels like the opening scene of a larger narrative – and makes you curious for the epic adventure to follow.

Reviewed by Andrew Fuhrmann

THEATRE

The Haunting of Spook Mansion (By Ghosts) ★★

Chapel Off Chapel, until November 23 This paranormal piss-take from comedy writer Michael Ward (Shaun Micallef’s Mad as Hell, RockWiz, I’m A Celebrity … Get Me Out of Here) sports well-known comedic talent. It’s flagrantly inane and does scrape the bottom of the proverbial, humour-wise, though it does also barrel along. Ghost-busting super-sceptic professor Adrian Chambers (Peter Houghton) has made a career debunking the supernatural. At a sparsely attended launch for his latest book, he’s buttonholed by hot librarian Beth Jackson (Emily Taheny) during the post-launch Q&A. Peter Houghton in The Haunting of Spook Mansion (By Ghosts). Credit: Darren Gill Yet the bookish Beth is no ordinary fan. She has a fiendish proposition for Chambers: $500,000 to spend the night in Spook Mansion, a notorious haunted house. Chambers nearly declines – crackpot offers are common in the paranormal investigation biz – but he needs the cash.

So begins a ridiculous comedy horror haunted by every trope in the book, including an elderly potato-seller with a terrible provincial accent (Ben Russell) to warn the stranger off. Spook Mansion goes all in for cheesy visual tricks: bookcases, sinister portraits, a fireplace with strange objects on the mantel. Beth will summon poltergeists and apparitions in a seance; the source of the clangour in the basement will be discovered. Houghton and Emily Taheny lean into myriad horror tropes. Credit: Darren Gill Why has Chambers been lured to this place? All will come to light, as murderous secrets are revealed and a diabolical plot unmasked. Some of the buffoonery relies on pop culture references aimed at Boomer and Gen X audiences, but there are enough shameless hijinks on offer, under Russell Fletcher’s direction, to get a giggle and a snort from anyone. As a mainstream lampoon of supernatural horror, The Haunting of Spook Mansion (By Ghosts) does the job, but it could be significantly improved. Plot points swarm the denouement like flying monkeys, in a way that makes final revelations difficult to follow. And the show sometimes feels like a TV comedy skit that got out of hand.

title: Wallabies player ratings: How the men in gold performed against Ireland
text:
5. Tom Hooper - 6.5 One of the Wallabies best on a night of underwhelming performances. Topped both the Wallabies’ carry and tackle counts. Was likened to Ireland’s impressive middle-rower Tadgh Beirne in the pre-game call, and while he’s not there yet, that’s a realistic ambition for the youngster, who is still only 24 and is arguably the Wallabies’ find (or re-discovery) of 2025. 6. Rob Valetini - 5.5 Took some big carries early in the first half and used his power in the contact zone. But fell out of the game in the second half. We haven’t seen the same game-changing talents from big Bobby V in the last few months.

7. Fraser McReight - 6 Pushed hard, and is always one of the Wallabies players searching to turn the game. Scored a well-taken try. But he was well negated by the Ireland forwards, and wasn’t rewarded by the referee for his 50-50 poaching opportunities. 8. Harry Wilson - 5 Another whose effort is never in question. Puts his hand up for carries and hard tackles whenever they’re needed. But the impact of those involvements ebbs and flows, and there is a question on Wilson’s dwindling battery level, too. No one will enjoy a post-tour break more.

9. Jake Gordon - 5 Kicking game was arguably a fraction off this week, with chasers rarely getting up for a contest. Gordon’s work when recycling on attack in Ireland’s red zone was sharp, but the problem was the Wallabies didn’t get to it more often. 10. James O’Connor - 4 Tough night for James O’Connor, who was thrown headfirst into the mincer by Joe Schmidt in Dublin. Not even in the squad for the tour until this week, he was called in and then immediately given a starting jersey. And then tasked with running an unwise attacking game plan. James O’Connor of Australia is tackled by Sam Prendergast. Credit: Getty Images

None of that excuses O’Connor’s skill errors. His rustiness was apparent. He was beaten in the air, too. But this was just another episode of the blindfolded darts game that is the Wallabies selection policy for the No.10. And it’s left us no closer to getting answers. 11. Harry Potter - 4 As said every week about Potter: a mixed game. But this time the good - some impressive defence - was outweighed by poor work under the high ball, both defensively and offensively, and being caught out of position. Schmidt rates Potter as strong in the air, but it hasn’t been apparent in recent outings. 12. Len Ikitau -5.5 Another who shone when the Wallabies had the ball in the Irish red zone, and were attacking directly. Ikitau plays as an extra back-rower in that zone, and also handles as a first receiver. A try was a good reward. But otherwise was passing out the back, and Ireland always had the answers.

13. Joseph-Aukuso Suaalii - 5.5 Filipo Daugunu of Australia jumps for the ball with Mack Hansen. Credit: Getty Images Looked for ways to enter the game on attack and defended intelligently. And was even one of the few Wallabies to take a clean catch under a high ball. Are we wedded to Suaalii at No.13? Hands up if you think he should be the Wallabies’ fullback against France. 14. Filipo Daugunu - 4 A big powerful ball runner, but had little opportunity other than one nice run, that was ruined by a loose inside pass. His high ball work was also not where it needs to be.

15. Max Jorgensen - 3.5 Park this one and move on. Not a night to remember for the young superstar, with errors aplenty, many of which led to Irish tries. High balls were dropped, there were knock-ons, and the usually unshakeable confidence of Jorgensen was clearly shaken. Kudos to Schmidt, perhaps, for backing him, but Jorgensen should have moved to the wing when Kellaway came on. Reserves 16. Billy Pollard - 5 Powerful running on display, and his try was a good reward. But losing the lineout in the 64th minute was a bad miss, and while the lift and jump were off, this has to be bread-and-butter stuff at Test level.

17. Tom Robertson - 4.5 Loading No major impact from Robertson, who keeps a scrum locked down and does his tight duties well. But he doesn’t threaten as a ball carrier. 18. Zane Nonggorr - 3.5 Penalised for collapsing his first scrum and then slow on lift on Frost for that crucial missed lineout.

19. Nick Frost - 3.5 Worked hard in a short time on the field, with eight tackles in 16 minutes. But then missed the key lineout and was binned for the last 10 minutes, which allowed Ireland to exploit his absence. 20. Carlo Tizzano - 4.5 Played a quarter but didn’t get sighted with any big plays. Like McReight, he couldn’t get on the ball. Question mark whether a second No.7 is a good use of the reserve back row slot, given McReight is an 80-minute player. 21. Ryan Lonergan - n/a

title: Meet the AFL prospect with the best kick in this year’s draft class
text:
Josh Lindsay starts each day the same way.

Ever since the Geelong Falcons’ top AFL prospect was about 12 years old, he wakes to an alarm, showers, then spends roughly 15 minutes honing his kicking skills – arguably the best in this year’s draft – in the family garage.

Josh Lindsay is set to be a first-round selection in the national draft. Credit: AFL Photos

There are footballs and boots scattered everywhere, goal posts on the back wall of the garage to aim at, and a rebound net to maximise how many kicks Lindsay can perform in a short period.

“It’s something a bit different that I do, but I think it goes a long way. I really enjoy doing it, so each morning I’m in the garage getting plenty of touches in before I attack the day,” he told The Age.

title: This is not acceptable: Wallabies woes paint bleak World Cup picture
text:
The Wallabies vs Ireland Test match in Dublin?

The staggering news, early, was that the Australians scored five – count’em – FIVE tries in the first half!

Less good was that it was Ireland’s fullback, and Canberra boy, Mack Hansen, who scored three of them – the first seeing him go over completely untouched to score under the posts, after clever Irish razzle-dazzle to frazzle the Wallabies’ defence.

But forget that! Our blokes were able to absorb those disasters and still come back into the match - despite our line-out continuing to malfunction, and so many unforced errors it’d kill a brown dog – by scoring two tries to make it 19-14 down at the break. It was further proof of what this year has already established - this generation of Wallabies has character and ability.

title: Metro Tunnel opening date revealed, taking passengers earlier than expected
text:
Melbourne’s Metro Tunnel will be taking passengers from November 30, more than a week earlier than expected.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese joined Premier Jacinta Allan on Sunday in announcing the opening date for the $15.5 billion project.

The pair met at Sunshine station, where both levels of government are funding a $4 billion upgrade of the rail network in the region, and caught a train into the tunnel before disembarking at the new State Library station for a tour.

The state government had previously revealed services would start from December, and it was widely believed the opening date would be on a Saturday or Sunday when services were less frequent.

title: ‘He’s blacked out’: Demolition derby car ploughs into crowd at NSW show
text:
Nine people have been injured, including a 54-year-old man who is in a critical condition with spinal injuries, after a car ploughed into the crowd at a demolition derby event in the state’s north-west on Saturday night.

Demolition derby driver Blake Taylor said his brother, Steven, had blacked out behind the wheel with his foot wedged on the accelerator before smashing through a perimeter fence into the crowd at Walcha showgrounds, 90 kilometres east of Tamworth, about 6.15pm on Saturday night.

Terrifying footage captured the moment of impact as the car demolished a temporary grandstand and sent people flying through the air.

A 54-year-old man with spinal injuries and a man in his 30s with a head injury were taken by helicopter to John Hunter Hospital in Newcastle in critical conditions.

title: Coalition attempts to present united front on climate policy | Midday News Bulletin 16 November 2025
text:
Listen to Australian and world news, and follow trending topics with SBS News Podcasts .





TRANSCRIPT:



The Coalition attempts to present a united front on climate policy

Pope Leo celebrates cinema in a meeting with Hollywood stars

Alex de Minaur says he will come back stronger after ATP Finals defeat

National Party Leader David Littleproud says he is pretty confident of reaching a deal with the Liberals to formalise the Coalition's position on net zero when they hold a joint partyroom meeting today.





After a party-room meeting earlier this week, the Liberal Party announced it would scrap its commitment to reach net zero emissions by 2050. It follows the same action taken by the Nationals earlier this month.





Opposition leader Sussan Ley says the party agreed its policy platform would be about energy affordability as an issue - and that could be achieved without the 2050 emissions reduction target.





She said the party platform would be for Australia to stay with the Paris Agreement.





Liberal Senator Jonathon Duniam told Sky News, the national interest would govern decisions made on emission reduction plans, called Nationally Determined Contributions, under the Paris Agreement.





"I think when you read Article 4 of the Paris Agreement in totality, there is provision for us to do what is in the national interest. And we would determine those contributions and the emission reductions effort in line with national interest. That means making energy more affordable. We have been doing ourselves a disservice. Climate change is settled - don't worry about that. It's not the debate here. It's about how you deal with the efforts our country puts in when it comes to emissions reduction."





**





The Bureau of Meteorology says the risk of severe thunderstorms remains active over the next 24 hours for parts of eastern Australia.





Hailstones, heavy rain and destructive winds have hit parts of New South Wales and Queensland on Saturday.





Southeast Queensland received more than 50 millimetres of rain recorded in 30 minutes - at multiple locations west of Brisbane.





And almost 3,000 properties were without power in southeast Queensland at 9pm on Saturday, according to Energex.





Angus Hines, from the Bureau of Meteorology, says the storm danger continues for eastern Australia before the focus shifts from Monday to parts of the country's north and west.





"Where these storms do develop, they could bring some pretty significant weather impacts with them. Damage to cars and property, particularly from the large and giant hail is absolutely possible. And we've seen that happen many times in the last few weeks. We could also see power outages, travel and transport delays as well as flash flooding."





**





Thousands have marched in the Brazilian city of Belem to call for climate justice and land rights at COP30.





The demonstration brought together Indigenous communities, Brazilian youth groups, and activists from around the world.





Indigenous activists have been protesting outside the COP venue, saying many have been excluded access to the proceedings.





Brazil's Minister of Indigenous Peoples, Sonia Guajajara, says 400 places out of 1,200 in Brazil's delegation were granted to Indigenous representatives.





Cristiane Puyanawa says she wants to be heard on the issue of Indigenous land rights.





"We are here today at the global climate march. Women, youths, Indigenous peoples, and river communities are united to demand social justice and the demarcation of Indigenous lands. Our land and our forest are not commodities. Respect nature and the peoples who live in the forest."





**





Australian actor Cate Blanchett says the pope's message on the vital role of cinema, actors and filmmakers is affirming and inspiring.





Screen stars Blanchett, Monica Bellucci, Chris Pine and Viggo Mortensen were among those invited to the private Vatican audience with the Pope to mark the 130th anniversary of cinema this year.





Pope Leo told the group that the logic of algorithms tends to repeat what works, but art opens up what is possible.





And he urged those involved in cinema to have the courage to keep tackling difficult subject matter.





"In the present era, there is a need for witnesses of hope, beauty and truth. Good cinema and those who create and star in it have the power to recover the authenticity of imagery in order to safeguard and promote human dignity. Do not be afraid to confront the world’s wounds. Violence, poverty, exile, loneliness, addiction and forgotten wars are issues that need to be acknowledged and narrated. Good cinema does not exploit pain; it recognises and explores it."





**





In Tennis, Alex de Minaur says he is already looking to come back even stronger after losing to Jannik Sinner 7-5 6-2 in the semis at the ATP Finals in Turin.





Sinner had to overcome first-set resistance from de Minaur until forging away in breathtaking fashion to set up a final against either world No.1 Carlos Alcaraz or Canadian Felix Auger-Aliassime.





De Minaur says he sees no other way, but to move forward.
